Sniper Elite is one of the best strategic, well mapped & true to its origins games of its genre. 
I bought the very first SE1 a number of years back & the game has still managed to maintain most of it's original ideas while evolving nicely with the times. 
Although it's sequel SE5, is unfortunately let down by a number of factors e.g. high memory leakage,bugs,etc.Though Rebellion are still patching the issues gradually, you will find most SE hardcore players still on SE4 servers.  
Multiplayer is very challenging and you will really need patience to play & to become good at, as there are some very committed players you will go up against (mainly camping & making nuisance of themselves by shooting you in the spine 5 seconds after you respawn!)
Tight team planning & a mic will make all the difference.
Co-op is likely the best mode & I have made a number of solid gaming pals over the last few years that are my age group(over 50's!) In fact I believe most of the players are middle aged. 
The rest of the community are pretty decent also and helpful to one another. 
SE4 is one of the best in the series IMO.
One of the most re-playable and realistic sniper focused games.
This is the best game in the entire franchise

It's very hard to take a "realistic" game seriously where a .30-06 to the face on "authentic plus mode" doesn't kill a man.

In other words, this is a sniper game where you can't reliably snipe because your sniper rifle specifically built to kill or disable a man from long distance isn't able to do that. Most enemies can easily shrug off at least 1 shot, some of them upwards of 5. Really, this game is just a "cool" cinematic killcam slapped onto a very mediocre and generic third person "stealth" shooter. The killcam is cool for the first 5 times, but then it gets repetitive and even disruptive to the gameplay, and the game simply does not have anything interesting to offer past that.
way to many cheaters with god mode on in the invade lobbies why play?

You are absolutely NOT incentivized in any capacity to go in guns blazing at any point - not unless you want to deal with an onslaught of Nazi's from every corner of the Earth and die repeatedly.  No.... You want to take your time. You want to go slow. You want to stealth your way through all the while getting those bad-ass kill shots; now that is where the joy of this game comes from. 

It reminds me a lot of Hitman with its huge open world maps, multi side objectives, and several gun type/kill challenges.  There are so many different ways to deal with everything too as the game also gives you a lot of different weaponry and you can fully customize your loadouts. 

Play it on hard and take your time, it's definitely worth it.

I just rated as not recommended so the review would show up. It's likely 90+% of people don't have an issue with my complaints regarding controls.

1. Most games allow for both a primary and secondary key binding. Not this game.
2. Only a select few controls can share the same key binding. 
3. Multiple keybindings for things that should at least optionally be the same.
4. No option for keys to be sticky

By default "e" is interact, but hold down "e" to search a body.  Except to pick up a document from a table is "r", which by default "r" is reload. Why not let the interact key also pick up a document? I can't say how often I've clicked "e" to pick up a document.
Zooming in using "b" binoculars uses left and right arrows, but with a scope it's up and down arrows (or vice versa I forget). Why not have up and down arrows be zoom in both? Then left and right to change range in scope?

Speaking of scope, when using a sniper rifle, right mouse must be held to keep the gun against shoulder, why? Why not hit right button once to engage scope and again to disengage? Then hit space to stop breathing, target and fire. With a laptop (and my preferred keyboard) this is stupidly difficult 

In fact playing on a laptop sucks because of keybinding limitations. Even using a full keyboard and mouse likely causes carpal tunnel.

I use a micro keyboard. It's about 6 inches wide.  The top 3rd is a touchpad that works exactly like a laptop touchpad. You can double tap with 1 finger for left mouse, 2 fingers acts like a scroll wheel, 3 fingers double tap is right mouse. Left of the touchpad is a left mouse button and on the right side a right mouse button. The top right corner has up/down/right/left and ok (enter).
Below the touchpad is a mostly standard qwerty keyboard. F1-F10 along the top, Tab, caps, left shift, left control. left alt, right alt windows are available; along with standard symbol keys. On the left of keyboard are larger left and right mouse buttons. On the right side is large page up and page down.

Now imagine this. Enemies are near, you want to use smg. Hold down left mouse to keep the gun shouldered, use w, s, a, d to move and the touchpad to aim. Now try to do all of that and figure out how to accurately fire. If not for right mouse having to be held, it would be possible, but not pleasant.

In sniper mode it's just frustrating. Hold down right mouse, hit space, try to aim then hit left mouse to fire. In my case, I have to hold the keyboard with at least three fingers and a thumb to stabilize the keyboard.  Left thumb hold right mouse button, right thumb hit space, then move to right thumb to touchpad to aim and try to figure out how to fire without dropping the keyboard. forget about trying to change the range (if zoom was up/down for both binocs and scope then changing range would work with left/right.

I then thought, I know, I'll use my awesome joystick as a game controller. It has an analog control with 4 buttons on top of the joystick, a fire button and secondary fire button all on a 3 axis joystick. The base has 6 additional keys and a throttle. Except if you select controller in game you can't adjust the keybindings. 

Fine, I'll use a joystick keybinder program.  10 keys, an analog joystick, fire and 2nd fire, a 3 axis joystick and throttle are not enough to satisfy all the major keybindings because the user can't determine how they wish the game to act and the developer thinks you need separate keybindings that do the same basic things.

In case the developer reads this, the following changes are needed.
1. Allow your user to select any keybinding they wish and alternate keybindings. if you want warn about conflicts, but don't make it a hard rule.
2. Allow the customer to chose if a keybinding is a switch (push once for on, push it again for off; in fact this should be the default it's not like you have to hold down the "r" key to reload)
3. Allow controller customization.

Remember that some of your customers may have disabilities.

As someone who has played the whole franchise through, I gotta say that "Sniper Elite 4:  ITALIA" is a bit of a let down.  There are about five main areas that I think have made it a let down.  

Stability:  The game is a genuine mess when it comes to stability, playing it when it has been out for 7 years, the game is still horribly unstable, with crashes frequently.  

Story:  Even though its the genre, the story feels to be lacking a lot of depth that you get from modern games, it feels more like I'm playing Conflict: Desert Storm, than a modern shooter with written characters.  It is exceptionally two-dimensional in its characters and plot, being neither here nor there, where it could choose to embrace the Nazi shooter genre like Wolfenstein, or try be a serious historical game, but kinda sits randomly in the middle making it just feel like a boring fictional story.  

Voice acting and general sound:  This maybe a personal thing due to my equipment, but the sound effects in this game are horrible, and the voice acting honestly quite average.  Possibly too its the artistic styling, but I almost hate hearing my character speak as its painfully bad, it sounds like a Steven Seagal film.   

Gameplay:  Sniper Elite has always been a bit ironically named, this one feels even more so like the Sniper element is gone, where in previous ones I felt like I was constantly trying to mask my shots and find vantage points, this one feels like I could just walk it with the SMG even on the harder settings.  There are more items etc than in previous games, but I feel like they have added little to the game.  

Price:  Come on guys, its 7 years old.  

Its an enjoyable game when it runs right, and the environment is beautiful like most Sniper Elite games, but its firmly a "buy when its on sale" game.

Let me start off by saying that I'm not a huge fan of the stealth action genre, and this is my first time playing a game in the Sniper Elite franchise. My only interest in the series was from my hunger to play something in the WW2 shooter genre; a sub-genre that used to dominate the 2000s that is pretty much all but dead in current year. I picked it up on sale, along with all of the DLC content, for a total less than $15. After finally finishing the base game and all the expansion missions, I have to say that I'm very impressed.

Aesthetic: The graphics look great, I especially love the attention to detail when it comes to the villages and buildings in general. A lot of care went into making these set pieces feel lived in (despite the lack of actual civilians). Each level plays out in an open world setting, giving you the freedom to do side quests, get collectibles, and strategically take out the enemy at your own pace. Some of these levels are pretty huge for being mini-open worlds. Seriously, if you took one and tripled the size, you could easily fit an entire game in it. The sheer amount of mini-open worlds keeps the game feeling fresh at pretty much all times.

Sound: Very classical, run of the mill, World War 2 sounding soundtrack. Not that this is a bad thing, but often times I kept the music muted and listened to podcasts or other music while playing. The voice acting is great for what it is. The protagonist sounds like your typical Nazi killing superhero that you'd expect in these sorts of games. There's also a pretty cool feature where different environmental events would completely drown out the ambiance. For example, you can use a plane taking off from a nearby runway to mask the sound long enough for you to get a stealth kill or two without being heard.

Gameplay: This is where the game shines the brightest, although the gameplay loop does get repetitive after a while. You can tell they tried their best to make the AI believable, but like every other stealth game I've played, they're kind of dumb and predictable. Some times they will stack up and get aggressive, and other times they just kind of wander around like the AI in Metal Gear Solid 2/3. 

You have your classic XP system, with a lot of weapons, traits, and inventory items to unlock. However, there are quite a few items hidden behind a paywall (not an issue if you get the season pass). 

The controls are flawless and feel completely natural. Character movement and response is exactly what I wanted it to be. There is a climbing element to it, but it's a little more realistic. You won't be climbing walls and jumping from roof to roof like in Assassin's Creed. The stealth kills are extremely satisfying, as there are a variety of ways to take out each enemy. The violence reminds me of those bone breaking moves you can do in Mortal Kombat. Time slows down, the enemy goes X-Ray vision, and you watch the bullet slowly pierce their eyeball and blow off the top of their skull. Or you can blow our their lung, neck, heart, intestines, kidneys, and even their nuts. Yes, time slowly down while you watch a guy's testicle slowly explode from a sniper round.

You also can use decoys, mines, bouncing betties, TNT, stick grenades, silencers, and can even call in indirect fire. The rifle/secondary weapon/pistol variety is also extremely satisfying and features all of the time era's greatest hits.

DLC: I was honestly annoyed at the paywall existing for some of the weapons. Even if it didn't effect me because of my season pass, it was still annoying to know it was there. That being said, the four extra missions easily make it worth it alone. 

Like the base game, all four missions exist in varied mini-open worlds. Each one having plenty of side objectives and side content, similar to the base game. I want to say I got about 8-10 hours out of all four missions, with the least impressive one being the Hitler one. I beat that in about 30 minutes or so. I killed a couple of troops, killed Hitler, killed a couple more troops, then sprinted for the exit site with machine gun fire spraying at me like an Indiana Jones scene. Kinda mindless. However, the other three missions were all very fun though, worth the price, and kept me busy for a while. 

Replayability: This is easily one of the most fun games I've ever played. Having just finished the campaign and expansions, I am definitely excited to revisit this game in the future and try again on harder difficulties. I would guess that it's probably good for two or three playthroughs tops, when all is said and done.

To me, the game shines when you play it on moderate difficulty/custom difficulty and on co-op mode with a friend and can use all of the cool extra targeting tools the game gives you with the HUD etc. The campaign gives you an open interpretation how to complete each level with you being able to pick and choose which objectives you do in what order and how you tackle them which is great. Everyone can implement their own strategies and order of doing things which adds some player expression and replayability. With that being said, I completed all of the achievements in this game and playing on the hardest difficulty feels like a totally different and less enjoyable game in my opinion. There's nothing drastically wrong with it but stealth in this game is very basic and playing yet another "don't stand in their cone of vision!" game is not that special. Maybe the higher difficulties are super fun for enthusiasts or purists of certain styles of gameplay but for me a bit more of a casual approach is the best. Overall it's a fun game and I'd recommend it if you enjoy third person stealth and sniping type games and even more so if you have a friend to play with but the harder difficulties are boring to me. There's no need to play this way, but it's just something to keep in mind if you want to explore the higher difficulty options like Authentic Plus at any point.

I have a weird relationship with Sniper Elite games. For the first few hours it's a super fun and exiting experience trying to be stealthy and pop some bollocks off a baddie. But somehow always after the ~15 hour mark it seems to get old for me. The story feels generic and the same in all of these games and the combat starts to get repetitive after the first few missions.
Nevertheless these are games that I can see myself jumping back in, playing a few missions and waiting for the next wave of inspiration to reinstall.
Also switching between agent 47 and full Rembo type of play style can have positive impact on the "having fun" aspect.

Personal recommendation: Play Authentic or authentic plus the first time through the campaign. I feel like I missed out on the real experience that each map/mission had to offer because running it on Elite difficulty was still (in my mind) a little too easy. Authentic difficulty really makes you use more of the map and mechanics of the game that you otherwise don't need on easier modes. It also makes the campaign feel more flushed out and each map/mission perceptibly has more content and therefore the game as a whole.

Sniper Elite 4 is a bit of an upgrade over it's predecessor. Graphically it's a little nicer and the game plays fairly well. The brutal kill shots are still a thing. In this game you play as a sniper who needs to infiltrate bases and your means of doing so mainly requires you to snipe your way through groups of enemies. Sometimes you can destroy vehicles by shooting out their gas tanks, but the main thing that makes this game cool is it's x-ray bullet time effect that shows your sniper bullet pass through the enemy's vital organs and it shows them being ruptured in slow motion. This is gratifying when you pull of a nice clean heart shot. It's even more satisfying when you shoot someone in the nuts and you see the testicle get ruptured. lol. 

Rating: 10/10

pretty fun sniper game

Very bad stealth. Buggy, can't even alt-tab without having to restart the game. Shitty collectibles and unnecessary DLCs for grabbing money. They also added tons of upgrades and literally none of them to help with stealth. Also, the hardest difficulty of the game just takes away the user interface, what a genius way to make the game harder, maybe take away my keyboard or mouse next time to make it harder.

If you like brute force shooting, you'll probably enjoy the game. If you prefer realism over fun gameplay, you'll enjoy the game.

To be fair, it's not much different to the previous games, just don't expect improvements.

Various small things I disliked that made the overall experience bad:
- Talking to various NPCs to get a briefing on each mission
- Killing enemies with other means is easier than killing them with a sniper, so much easier that they had to add aim assist to the snipers. Especially for stealth, you almost can't snipe in the game.
- Collectibles
- More upgrades than you can eat
- This stupid dancing every time I try to prune is still here

Got this game during the Steam sales season, extremely worth the $4.00 spent. People said this one is the best in the franchise and it truely is.

Pros:
+ Gun selection and utilities:
Moderate amount of gun in the arsenal, each of them is unique and have their own pros and cons. Not only that, you can carry up to three different firearms and some other items such as medkits, wire trap, grenades that can be used creatively by the player.

+ support multiplayer:
 I haven‚Äôt try it out cause I couldn‚Äôt get my friends to buy it. But look for others player‚Äôs video, it‚Äôs certainly help lengthen the game time.

+ bullet ballistics:
Within difficulty selection, you can choose to play with ‚Äùrealistic‚Äù bullet physic where the winds and air resistance will affect your bullet trajectory and give you a more authentic experience.

+ Multiple missions and replayability:
 The missions while lack in numbers, made a great job in their designs. This is including the buildings, environments and the backgrounds.
 You can go back to any mission and play it out as many different ways as you can think of. Either blowing someone up of with a landmine or trick them running into a wire trap, it‚Äôs your call.

+ Multiple modes:
There are multiple game mode beside campaign such as cooperative mode and wave survival. 

Cons:
+ Story is not that interesting. (No spoiler)

+ Junky movements:
I know this is a sniping game where you should stay at one spot and sometimes move to other but if you play like a maniac with a shotgun or a smg like me, it‚Äôs just clunky when you stay near an obstacle. Some small rock that looks like can be climbed on will stop you or even make you stuck entirely.

Overall, 9.5/10. A solid game, worth every cents.

I recommend buying the Deluxe Pack if you only want to play Sniper Elite 4 only.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Fun game. Unfortunately it doesn't have cloud saving for some reason, so when my old hard drive died on me, I lost everything. I was level 52, had almost every weapon mastered, every collectible, and then it all went away. But the game still lists many of these accomplishments on the leader boards if I go look, but when I go into my own game I'm level 1 again with nothing unlocked or completed. So if you buy it, make sure to back up your saves on an external drive just in case.

EDIT: A friend gave me a copy of his save that had almost everything that I had so I can play the game again.

I've first played this game back when it was in Alpha-stage (at Gamescom 2016, Cologne, Germany). Instantly liked it. (I bought 3 as well but went for a refund on that - see my review on that one to know why). It's slightly over 5 years old now this game. But it still works/looks good.

So slightly over 3 hours now into this game. And only in my 2nd (real) mission so far. The AI really looks out for the fellow AI. When someone's suddenly missing, they will come look. A lot of tough opponents (snipers, boats, etc.). And a lot of ways to kill the enemy.

Can't wait for part 5. Already saw some things.

So, you've got Sniper Elite 4‚Äîlike a war movie, but interactive, yeah? Graphics are top-notch, Italian landscapes that make you wanna send a postcard. Kill cams? They're Tarantino meets Picasso‚Äîbloody, yet artistic.

Gameplay? It's sniping elevated to an art form. Ballistics, open-world freedom‚Äîfeels like you're orchestrating chaos. Story's like a war-themed backdrop to the main act, not stealing the show, but adding flavor.

Soundtrack's decent‚Äîgunfire, explosions, wartime vibes. It's not Beethoven, but it gets the blood pumping.

Levels? Picture a tactical wonderland in Italy. Vantage points, stealth corners‚Äîit's a strategic playground.

Replay? It's like they're begging you to come back. Open-ended missions, secrets‚Äîlike your favorite buffet. Co-op multiplayer? Sharing the joy of precision kills.

Overall, Sniper Elite 4 is the Picasso of precision shooters. For war game lovers, it's not just a game; it's a bloody masterpiece.

SE4 is a very good game. I remember playing SE2 and a little bit of SE3 and found the movement to be quite clunky, and the gun-play as well.
Now, SE4 is great, which doesn't mean the movement is perfect now- on the contrary, it's fine now but still leaves a lot to be desired and that's the great thing about this series, you know when you've perfected a certain formula you keep on wondering there's no way this series can be improved- the subsequent sequels feel kinda stale. But you can just play SE4, enjoy it immensely and feel it in your bones the huge potential this series has. This series has still hasn't peaked yet, which gives me a lot of hope for it's future.
The gunplay is great here- Rifles are great, as you'd expect from a SE game; using pistol is also really satisfying and made close quarter stealth so much fun; and the smgs- well they aren't the most accurate but I think that's intentional and you can upgrade them to have better handling and accuracy.
Now the major change from previous SE games is that unlike previous titles which were very linear, SE4 is more openworld type- not completely but each mission is set on a pretty big area and has multiple objectives which you can tackle in any way you want. This is a great welcome change. Each mission can take around 1hr or more depending on your playstyle. It took me around 18 hrs to get through the main campaign which had 8 missions (which were all mostly great). I've yet to do the DLCs but I've heard they're pretty good.
There are many more good things to say about SE4 but I'd like to list out what I think needs improvement.
- Context sensitive jumps, you can't grab small ledges in some cases, you can climb some pipes other times you can't. It's all very inconsistent and reminded me of how great Splinter Cell did these things. This is related to movement.
- Stealth is good, but can definitely be much better. Sometimes enemies can spot you from 200m, sometimes they can't see you right in front of them. They also act pretty dumb when they see a dead body. But I definitely like the specific actions and details.
- Weapon upgrade system. It's good that you're making sure the player actually uses the gun to upgrade them but it's a big grind. Like I played the entire campaign and mastered only the silenced pistol, and did a few upgrades for 2 riles and a smg. Killing 100 soldiers only after tagging them is not fun and takes a lot of time. I wish more thought was put behind this.
- Story. I don't think anyone really cares for the story in SE, and this is the last thing I would look for as an improvement in future titles. But it can be done.

These were some of the big issues I had with the game. But even so, I had so much more fun than I had expected. For the price I paid, SE4 IS really sweet. There's not many games in this genre so it also scratches a particular itch. And you know what- there's a small series called FarCry, it's made by a realtively small indie studio called Ubisoft. I think they can learn a thing or two about sniping, elevation, verticality and stuff.
In conclusion, SE4 is pretty good. 8.5/10

I own this game for a while and enjoyed it very much.
What I like is the bullet drop mechanics, wind, gravity, etc,,,
What I DON'T like is when it doesn't work how it should !!!

You have indicators that tell you at what distance your bullet drops.
For every 100 meters there's a indicator.
So when my enemy is 125 meters from me, I assume it's between the 100 meter and the 200 meter indicator.

So when I start shooting like my sniper rifle is a machine gun, and I'll keep missing my target.
I activate the aim assist to see where I should be aiming.
I was very suprised to see that the indicator was between 0 and 100 meters.
And NOT between 100 and 200 meters.

How can this be?
Something in this game doesn't work properly..
I don't want to,, but in order to play this game you must use aim assist indicator.

This often happens with targets further than 100 meters.

No one is Going to read this review so i want to confess that i am gay

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I have bought this game twice - first on Nintendo Switch, where I played for about 70 hours and completed all achievements/challenges in the main game, then on Steam where I have played up to the second DLC mission. I hope to get around to finishing the DLC missions very soon, but I don't expect my review to change, that is... I really love this game! I have already bought SE5, because I know I will like it... except for the non-lethal ammo, which I will try to play around.

I play on Steam Deck with good graphics and framerate settings, and profit from always-on gyro controls for precise aiming. Both on the Switch and the Deck, I have played through all levels on "Authentic (Hardcore)" mode, then "Authentic Plus" mode [up to DLC 2 on the Deck]. I have never played on one of the easier modes, because I feel like the various aim-assisting features are not consistent with a game that has "sniper" in the title. I have Kill Cam (or whatever it's called) turned off, because I'm there for stealth and sniping, not an action film or FPS experience. That being said, when it all goes to hell and I aggro a load of enemies, I do get that experience too! It always feels great to make a good long shot by leading a running enemy while compensating for wind and distance. There is good variety in the weapons, even if there are some that are clearly better or worse than others, and it is pleasant to upgrade your preferred weapons over time.

One thing that stands out for me about SE4 is how well it recreates the locations. I doubt that any other game evokes 1940s Italy as well as this*. You can [i]smell[/i] the interiors in the maze of houses at Bitanti. You can [i]smell[/i] the oil and the sea in the vast structure outside the sub pen in the first DLC mission.
*Like, I have not witnessed 1940s Italy in person, but I have been to Italy a few times, to many military museums, on high mountains, in maritime installations, inside period ships, and have perused countless antique and vintage shops; the landscapes and buildings in the game viscerally evoke the Mediterranean, and the interior scenes evoke the smell of real period paraphenalia and furniture.

Negative aspects of the game are... I can only think of occasional enemy AI glitches and predictatability. Maybe the interior part of the last level of the campaign does not really fit with the rest of the game, and the last "enemy" that you fight does not fit with the playstyle of any other part of the game. And of course bullet drop and windage are exaggerated because of the technical limitations of a computer simulation, but they are consistent within the game, so this is not really a negative.

I paid ‚Ç¨9 on sale for the complete version of the game, which is already excellent value, without having yet played the last DLC missions.

Rating: 8/10

The game's protagonist, Karl Fairburne, once again takes center stage with his sniper expertise, and the improvements to the ballistics system are nothing short of impressive. The satisfying bullet physics, coupled with the iconic X-ray kill cam, deliver an unparalleled sense of accomplishment with each perfectly executed shot. The level of realism adds an extra layer of immersion, making every engagement a unique and pulse-pounding experience.

The open-world approach in Sniper Elite 4 enhances the overall gameplay experience. The expansive maps encourage exploration and strategic planning, allowing players to choose their preferred playstyle. Whether you prefer the stealthy approach, silently eliminating enemies one by one, or opting for a more action-packed assault, the game accommodates a variety of playstyles, providing a sense of freedom and replayability.

In conclusion, Sniper Elite 4 is a triumph in the realm of tactical shooters. Its combination of stunning visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, and historical authenticity make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned sniper or a newcomer to the series, Sniper Elite 4 offers an exhilarating and satisfying experience that will keep you coming back for more. It's a true testament to Rebellion Developments' commitment to delivering top-notch gaming experiences.

* Incompetent AI
* After a quick-save, the environment state can be reloaded, causing bodies and alarms to disappear.
* Inconsistent enemy vision: sometimes they can spot you based on a single pixel, triggering an alarm, while other times you can run right past them unnoticed.
* There is no option for "full stealth." For example, you are required to detonate the guns instead of disabling them quietly; there is no non-explosive alternative.
* Poor level design: In certain cases, there is only one entrance to a building, even for non-primary targets.
* Broken patrol routes: Enemies can randomly change patrol routes and/or have zero blind windows for a stealthy approach.
* You can't apply skins to certain weapons.
* Kill cam looks cool only first 50 kills or so. Sometimes it works, sometimes not.

The game has a solid core idea and mechanics, but its execution lacks variety and requires polishing.

[h1]Stealth and Action[/h1]

If you're into stealth games, this is the game for you.

The AI in this game is amazingly well done. You honestly feel like you're in a real world. The game really encourages you to think about what you're going to do before you do it. Yeah, you can try to kill everyone and if you just want to go in there blasting the place apart, by and large you can do it, but if you want to stealth, you can do that too. I played scenarios where I did most of the mission without killing anyone. It was heartpounding fun to slip in between patrols, throw rocks to lead guards away from doors I needed to get into, leaving traps in remote locations to be set off to draw enemies away from my location. All of it fun and seemed very legit.

Remember how you'd come up on 5 guys, and you'd throw rocks to pull them one at a time to your location and kill them all? Yeah, well here is the bad news. These boys have learned to count. When one of their group goes missing, they notice and start looking for him. Yeah, enjoy that.

Storyline was good. Held together by a fairly thin thread it will get you through, but that's about it. Mostly this game is about tactical scenarios that you need to solve.

Which brings me to a very, very cool part of the game. Realistic mode. They decided to put in a realistic mode in the game. All your superpowers are basically gone. No minimap, no detailed info on the camp, no automatic gun site adjustment for distance and wind. All gone. All I can say is good luck. Be prepared for many, many heart pounding moments.

Multiplayer also offers some added fun although I did not play much of that. Would have preferred if there was an option to limit the sniper role to one (perhaps random) player per side rather than having squads of snipers which can sometimes result in a lot of camping and makes for a boring match. 

An amazing game if you're into stealth games!

Despite the bugs that were never corrected when this game, created by Valve and bought by Rebellion, was bought out, part 4 is still the best of the 5 (especially given how bad part 5 was).


[h1]A. NON-EXHAUSTIVE LIST OF BUGS[/h1]
[b]1. [/b] Survival mode > map set > Loss of [i]Binocular Check[/i] (list the contents of dead enemy soldiers with binoculars) in survival mode. The loss of this feature varies between the end of wave 8 or the beginning, 9 or 10 at the most.

[b]2.1 [/b] Survival mode > map [i]Urban[/i] > [i]The Wall Bug[/i] which is present at various points in the map: a soldier gets stuck and treads water.
[list]
[*] Balcony next to the terrace of the "radio house" (because a radio is present in this house in Campaign mode). Some calls it : "German house" or "Propaganda house" but it's a wrong name, Propaganda Miniseter's house in Campain mode is Est side, opposite to his radio house.
[*] Radio house > under the stairs, in the wall.
[*] Base / Post Command area #2, south wall side > Under the stone staircase.
[*] [i]Square Tower[/i] (between Bases / Post Command #1 and #3) > in the first floor walls.
[/list]
There are others in this map, which is the one with the most bugs.

When they're not visible, they can't be killed with primary or secondary weapons. To kill them, you must use one of the following: 
[list]
[*] Sticky grenades,
[*] TNT with timer, 
[*] Flar in grouped mode (Rocket to request grouped or ungrouped artillery fire),
[*] Panzerfaust.
[/list]

[b]2.2 [/b] Survival mode > Always on map [i]Urban[/i] > [i]The Stepping bug[/i] :
[list]
[*] Maison de la radio > on the terrace, against the south wall > a soldier walks in place against the low wall. He frees himself as soon as he receives an enemy shot that misses or only wounds him.
[/list]

[b]3. [/b] Survival mode > Facility map > Vehicule's Bug ;
[list]
[*] Most often found on troop transporters, but also on AB-41s, which can remain levitating, like Star Wars ships, or straddling the terrain.
[/list]

[h1]B. BONUS #1[/h1]
The uninitiated may think it's cheating, but it's really just a bonus ([b]Easter Egg[/b]) from the game's original developers: cross the red lines to play, not out of the game, but out of the map (Map).
As far as I know, there are 3 different moves to make, which are a set of key combinations for crossing red lines:
- Crouch + aim: doesn't allow you to cross all the lines, especially in front of certain staircases, it doesn't work.
- Crouch + cable mine: does not allow you to cross all the lines, especially in front of certain staircases, it doesn't work.
- Run + crouch + aim: works everywhere.

Playing in Authentic Plus mode only, it's a real treat, spicing up the difficulty level to its maximum in Survival mode. You need a team strategy, and a mastery of defense strategies (mines, ambushes, etc.).
The best thing is to have at least two players outside map, so you can share areas and help each other out if need be.

It's much more difficult to play outside maps, especially as each map has its own rules and limits: they all differ in terms of the extent that can be explored and used, otherwise you'll fall through the floor, into a black hole and die.


[h1]C. BONUS #2[/h1]
Survival Mode > map [i]Facility[/i] ([i]Center[/i]). In addition to bonus #1, in this map only, another special move performed at a single specific location allows you to go above the entire complex (bunker, hills, etc.) above Base / Post Command #1. Particularly in the steel marine observation turret, where bullets from enemy soldiers only ricochet and cannot pass through the steel dome.
This is the only map with a #2 bonus.  The "Marina" map also features a different movement for crossing red lines, but only functional in one place: the wooden house, via the small secondary room. This is of no use once you've mastered the general movement to cross all the red lines.


[h1]D. INTERACTIVITY BETWEEN PLAYERS[/h1]
It is not possible to exchange material between players during a map, with the exception of :
[list]
[*] TNT (Simply throw it on the ground for the other player to pick it up, as with other equipment).
[*] Mines S,
[*] Cable mines / Trip mines,
[*] Flat / anti-tank mines.
[/list]

But it's not possible to exchange: 
[list]
[*] Weapons that are part of each player's basic equipment,
[*] Ammunition,
[*] Medical kits and bandages,
[*] Grenades,
[*] Flar (rocket to request grouped or ungrouped artillery fire).
[/list]


[h1]E. MY OPINION[/h1]
A game that doesn't tire (with a few temporal pauses since its release in February 2017) in Survival mode, because the campaign mode and its 4 DLC, after a few hundred or some thousand hours of play, we've come full circle, and in fewer hours than that. It's all about the team, the teammates who radically change the gameplay experience in Survival mode.

To this end, this game cannot be appreciated or mastered without a good headset: sound is the essential component for hearing where enemies are coming from and what kind of noise they are making, how many of them there are, even what type of soldier they are, and where they are coming from and/or going.

The microphone allows you to synchronize quickly and in real time the exact position of snipers, vehicles, troops, and the death or destruction of all this little world.
Authentic plus? Frustrating but fun. Great game all around.

I bought Sniper Elite 4 seeing as it was cheap and what a god awful mistake that was because how the hell is this game even remotely enjoyable?

I played this for only 1.4 hours and thank f**k it wasn't any longer otherwise I couldn't have refunded this pile of piss!

The game is about as easy as wearing a hat and that's on EVERY difficulty level even with EVERY assist feature OFF!

I swear whoever it was who programmed these Germans has put them on a five second delay because by the time an enemy loads a weapon I've already riddled the fool full of holes.

The apposing German force may as well be heavily armed preschool children due to the fact they can't shoot a firearm to save their lives and can't even remotely pose a challenge.
Meanwhile you can just sprint around the map like a mad man who kills like it's nothing.

The actual game environment itself looks beautiful but it means nothing when it's an environment in a garbage game such as this one.
Sniper Elite 4 is all just smoke and mirrors with nothing but flashy killing animations and it's vast environments and I certainly want more than that in a game.

I can safely conclude that Sniper Elite 4 is definitely NOT WORTH the money even if it's on special and that's saying something!

Good game. Great with two players. Not being able to heal yourself once your are bleeding out with bandages and medkits does not seem realistic as you can still shoot at enemies while bleeding out. It would not be that much to ask if explosives could blow closed doors and blocked entries away. Even if there is nothing there, it would increase the level of realism. Having completed Sniper Elite 4 on solo and then Sniper Elite 5 on solo and then coming back to play Sniper Elite 4 multiplayer, it adds a whole new dimension as real players are not as predictable. Cannot wait until Sniper Elite 6! For those who like Division or Ghost Recon, this game challenges you more by not getting hit in the first place or face dire consequences more often. There are no random ammo boxes laid out along the way forcing you to kill for most everything you need once your basic starting supplies run out.  The tie in to the history lessons is nice as it teaches a thing or two about past events.  Overall, I think the developers did a great job!

Extremely well done sniper game. The ultra efficient game engine runs like a charm on almost any gaming system. Level layout is superb, with many pathways to hide and flank. On higher difficulties tactics are not only recommended but necessary to ensure survival against the AI. Choose from a range of difficulty settings, from arcade to sniper elite with wind, bullet drop and less HUD elements adding extra challenge and realism. Extra fun in coop!

On a sale the expansion DLCs provide good value. The new levels are of above average quality, with Target Fuhrer being the standout.

Rating: 8.5/10

I would give this a solid 6-7 out of 10.  It is fun for what it is, you are an overpowered WW2 sniper who also can use every other gun still destroy most enemies if you have patience.  This is a game that I enjoyed the campaign, but will probably never play through a second time.  It is worth probably 15-20 dollars TOPS, but for a sale price of much cheaper than that, its a fun game.  I never played the multiplayer, just the campaign.  
Beware, this game does take some patience, you can go in and run-and-gun, but you will have to run away and hide and pick off enemies after they become alerted.  I played the next one in the series after this one and that was essentially the same game with some improved environments and enemies. 
The missions always give you a similar cue of things to do, but switch up the way it wants it done (stealth, poison, blowing up, etc.)  Its kind of like a WW2 Hitman game, but with little/no blending in with crowds.

Good game if you like WW2 setting, have patience, and want to blow stuff up (including Nazi testicles.)

This game was a ton of fun.  A good number of levels, primary and secondary objectives, collectibles, challenges, unlockables, weapons, tools, etc.  You can play the game as stealthily or as loudly as you like.  The big gimmick, obviously, is the sniping.  The difficulty for your character's stats, enemies and aiming can be customized.  At its hardest, sniping is much more complex than in other games.  There's distance, wind, heartbeat, sound masking, etc.  It will take a lot of time to get used to.  Otherwise, you can tell the game to make sniping as simple as point-and-click.

Pretty standard WWII fantasy story.  Nothing special, but not bad either.  The main character is pretty likable; typical hardened Allied soldier.

You can customize up to four separate loadouts, depending on the weapons and tools you've unlocked.  There are primary, secondary and sidearm weapons, all of which have different challenges to unlock upgrades and skins.  There are other tools you can add to your loadout, such as medkits, grenades, traps, etc.  There are also unlockable skins/characters.  I call them skins because all story dialogue is still the main character's, even if you use a woman.

The vast majority of the game's hours will be spent getting collectibles, completing challenges, mastering weapons and earning achievements.  For a casual gamer, this is no big deal.

Completionists, however, beware.  Not only do the challenges and achievements range from simple to extremely difficult, a great deal of them depend on co-op or multiplayer.  There are only two co-op levels and they cannot be played solo.  I tried starting a co-op game by myself and it proactively prevented me because I was the only one in the lobby.  Normally, I don't care about such a thing, but a couple achievements require you to get all collectibles and beat all challenges, including the co-op ones.  This, along with the fact that this game's multiplayer servers are basically barren by now, you will likely never truly 100% this game.

I say this to developers in a lot of reviews:  I should not have to sell your game to my friends or family just to fully complete it.  Nor should I have to beg total strangers on Steam forums to play with me.  That's some serious bullcrap and you should feel bad for your stupid decisions.

Despite these easily overlooked flaws, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys action shooters.

Sniper Elite (both 4 and 5) get a simple mechanic right that so many other games and series fail to do. That is seamless integration of singleplayer and co-op/multiplayer. 

We are in 2023, there is no need for devs to lock themselves into a single-player mindset. The technology is there, and skimping on a bit of netcoding that a modder could do in a few hours with access to the source code is short-sighted and a mistake. 

Rebellion has made their game infinitely more re-playable and enjoyable, and they were smart enough to do it without even needing to write a great story. While their games might not win GOTY, they have proven that they understand what players actually want.

This is how I imagined a perfect Spliter Cell sandbox game if Ubisoft still was able to produce good AAA games, with good content, without unncessary bussywork. It mixes the best aspects of SC: Blacklist with leveldesign of new Hitman trilogy, where each mission is in a completely different environment and has a big replayability. The gameplay itself is a lot of fun, thanks to AI being designed exactly as it should be in a good sniper-focused game. You will easily alert all enemies in a nearby area, but as long as you keep relocating,  smartly place traps, and use environmental hazards to your advantage, you will keep enemies clueless about your position, and thanks to a lot of tools to choose from, you can easily realize your ultimate predator power fantasy. Sniper Elite 3 was already a great game, but here they fixed the annoying aspects, and made a near perfect sniper game. However, there are still some aspects which needs to be flashed out, to push it from AA to AAA production level.

Pretty much exactly the same as 3 but with more open and larger maps. 

I'm not sure why they tried to have a meaningful story. It tries too hard and accomplishes nothing, and some of the dialog and voice acting is pretty bad despite only having a handful of cutscenes. The ascent there trying to do comes off as very goofy. Usually i wouldn't mind but again it takes itself too seriously so its hard to laugh at.    

Honestly the SE formula has gotten pretty stale there not doing enough to change things up, so after playing for about an hour i decided to rush through the game as fast as a could and i had more fun than i did playing normally. After doing this i  realised you could realistically beat the game in a stupidly quick time. I'm convinced you can easily beat this game if you play on the easiest difficulty and only do the main missions you can beat the game in under 2 hours pretty easily and get a refund. It uses side missions to artificially pad out the game, most of them are identical to the main quest objectives. Find this dude, kill another, find a document, things like that. It doesn't affect the story in anyway, you just get more XP. Not like it matters tho you unlock all the guns at level 5 anyway, apart from the the DLC weapons witch i'm 100% not gonna pay for.   

This is probably going to be the last SE game i play, its gotten so repetitive over the years. I might come back if they do something interesting in the future but i doubt that will happen anytime soon.

This game is a lot of fun. All of the levels have a high replay value with a variety of methods to complete your various objectives. The extra challenges are fun too once you've beat the game. The movement mechanics can be a little clunky at times but overall it isn't bad. I wouldn't consider this a run and gun FPS kind of game. It requires more strategy and stealth overall to complete the missions. Setting tripwire mines for enemy patrols, or luring enemy soldiers into traps by throwing a rock to get them to investigate the sound are also very fun dispatch methods of the enemies. The weapons selections is good, probably could have been a little more evenly balanced as far as the rifle choices though, there is one that ends up being considerably better than others. The DLCs are enjoyable too so I recommend them. Two thumbs up on this one.

here is a positive review of Sniper Elite 4:

Pros:
1. Excellent graphics and visual effects that make the game feel realistic and immersive.
2. The gameplay is challenging and requires strategic thinking and planning.
3. The variety of weapons and gadgets available to the player adds to the fun and excitement of the game.
4. The ability to customize your loadout and upgrade your weapons adds a layer of depth to the game.
5. The game offers a great single-player campaign with plenty of missions to keep you engaged for hours.

Cons:
1. The game can be quite difficult, which may be frustrating for some players.
2. The AI of the enemy soldiers can be a bit predictable at times, which can take away from the realism of the game.
3. The multiplayer mode can be hit or miss, with some players experiencing connection issues or lag.
4. Some players may find the game's emphasis on sniping to be limiting, as it may not appeal to those who prefer a more action-packed gameplay style.
5. The story can be a bit generic and predictable, which may not appeal to those looking for a more engaging narrative experience.

[h1] Sniper Elite 4 is a 2017 third-person tactical shooter stealth video game developed and published by Rebellion Developments.  [/h1]

[b]Spoiler warning. [/b]

In the quickest way I can say it, it's that [b]Sniper Elite 4 doesn't exceed in anything nor fail at anything.[/b] If you want a fun sniper game for a few hours with a NOT that interesting story and not hardcore - realistic sniping, you should definitely consider getting this, [i]albeit at a good sale, because I don't think paying the full price tag is a smart choice here.[/i]

Now, to get a little in depth, let's talk about some important points briefly, to get an understanding of the place of this game and how you should be treating it:

[b]I. First of all, story.[/b] Well.. I can't really say it's good. In fact, it's really not good, but for what it is, it does the job. You as the gamer, are really playing SE4 for the exciting stealth sniping action. Story is set in Italy in the year of 1943 - directly tying to it's prequel (or predecessor) - Sniper Elite 3. In short, the story is about the nazis making a new super weapon that no one really know what is, but one thing the americans know [spoiler](yes obviously you play as an american ally don't be surprised it's one of those stories)[/spoiler], that it needs to be destroyed from german hands before they can use it. Original, I know. You shouldn't take the campaign too seriously, so you don't get disappointed.

[b]II. Gameplay (and level design) [/b] is very easy to understand, but hard(er) to master. You have loads of stuff to play with. From different kinds of traps to rocket launchers, flare guns, airstrikes, and a lot of other fun stuff. In this case, you will never really get tired and say that the selection is poor.

[b]III. Gunplay: [/b] Sniping, being the main focus of the game, feels great. It's snappy, responsive and all that good stuff. The puncture camera is a good addition as in any Sniper Elite game, but you get tired of it the more you play. While sniping is great, sadly thats not the case with other weapons - ARs, pistols and such weapons don't have "first-person aiming" but rather just the crosshair getting smaller. Which means you can have a perfectly lined shot with an assault rifle only to shoot it and miss so badly that you don't really wanna touch assault rifles again. The guns are very unpredictable where they shoot and it is rather off-putting, but this gun mechanic was seen in the former games also.

[b]IV. Graphics:[/b] simply said - spectacular. For being a game from 2017, it really doesn't show it's age. Every level starts with a Wow! moment, where you think you're looking at an image from real life. Graphics in SE4 are very good and I find it being a strong point, especially with great colors and great image of Italy in 1940s.

[b]V. Characters:[/b] Now this is something that will be debatable. Characters that we interact with throughout the story are niche, but nice. You never want to hate any of your allies, because they never tell you to go do stupid crap. They are quite likeable, even though we don't get to really know them very deeply. There is one thing that was strange with all characters, being the voice acting. I have noticed this trend in a few other Sniping related games and I never get it. Voice acting is very off - lifeless, hard on the ears, absolutely not realistic, very bass heavy and just not good sounding on the ears. Seems like the resources for SE4's voice acting werent very big. It's a thing that maybe not many people will really care about, but it is something to note.

[b]DLC content: [/b] I think that too much content is restricted behind paid DLC. The base game does offer a good selection of weaponry, but if you look at it for a little longer, you'll see that there are more DLC weapons than base game weapons. DLC missions on the other hand are good, and definitely worth buying if you just wanna squeeze that little more fun from this game.

[b]To sumarize, Sniper Elite 4 is a good package of fun. [/b] BUT. It has one huge flaw, that I would consider to be really bad if I wouldn't mention it: [b]BAD level design.[/b] It is made in such way, that you have to either - have too much time on your hands to wait for the AI to relocate, or make a stupid trap in the lowest of bushes (where enemies don't apparently see you even though you can be -realistically said- seen from a mile away), where 10 soldiers with go and die, while making them come to you with hearing a sound from throwing a stone, in many cases they don't because you've alerted them already and they are literally GLUED to their position. Which leads to... going loud in many more cases than one would like. I found that there are not enough secret passageways or off-routes to plan a good sniper attack. Well of course, you do have many tools at hand with you, but if you JUST wanna try to snipe of a camp of guys stealthly, it almost never works out because THE ONE THING THEIR AI KNOWS TOO WELL IS FINDING DEAD BODIES. It gets frustrating after a while when you're progressing through the campaign missions. 

[b]My opinion: [/b] Likeable, but not memorable. It doesn't do anything differently than other Sniper Elite games, but for some, it may be a good thing. As I've said before, it's a good bit of fun but NOT for full price. If you enjoy sniping games and the Sniper Elite franchise as a whole, you will like this one also, but it won't be a breathtaking experience. You'll want to finish it, but you'll be relieved that it ended rather than wanting to replay it again.

First time playing Sniper Elite franchise, read reviews that SE4 was the best and on sale.  I was glad I picked it up, I like the calculated estimation of quick sniping bullet trajectory.

The big con of this game, is playing on 'authentic' removes HUD, and with it map objectives. That's a real pain, because every mission ended with the last 20mins me sprinting around the empty murdered base trying to find the objective interactions. They could of added markers on the map and still been realistic!  

So instead i guess they assume you have played on normal difficulty first to learn the map objectives, or look it up online like it did for my play-through.

highly recommend for shooters, and people who like to calculate the shot. Haven't even played the 2 player coop, im sure thats even better. and adds a little more content re-playability. Now I did not do it as a completionist, if you love 100% a game, this has a lot to do on the maps, and if you are the type to keep playing a level to memorize it, and just repeatdly like taking npc out, you will enjoy this. This game is still relevant. It has the feel of an older first person shooter except for the fact that the maps are open. Sniper Elite 4 is a game that truly immerses you in the gritty reality of World War 2. The game offers an unparalleled level of freedom, making it the most advanced WW2 shooter I've ever played.

The game's tactical third-person combat is both challenging and rewarding. It requires strategic thinking and precision, making every successful long shot feel like a significant achievement. The gameplay choices available add depth and variety to the game, ensuring that no two playthroughs are the same.

One of the standout features of Sniper Elite 4 is its gigantic levels. The scale of the game world is truly impressive, providing a vast playground for you to explore and strategize within. The detailed environments, from the sun-drenched Mediterranean coastal towns to the colossal Nazi megastructures, are not only visually stunning but also add to the overall immersion of the game.

For those who enjoy a challenging, strategic shooter with a rich narrative and expansive game world, Sniper Elite 4 is a must-play. It's a game that truly captures the essence of being a sniper in World War 2."

"Sniper Elite 4" is a third-person shooter (TPS) game developed and published by Rebellion Developments. The game is set on the Italian Front of World War II and offers players the opportunity to conduct covert operations on large maps and utilise their sniper skills.

Sniper Experience: The highlight of the game is that players experience the ability to use their sniper skills and neutralise enemies by shooting targets from a long distance.

Large Maps and Open World: "Sniper Elite 4" takes place on large and detailed maps. Players can freely move around these maps and complete missions by developing different strategies.

Targeting and Tactics: Players can develop tactics to identify and approach their targets. They can choose various approaches such as stealth, improvisation, or remote aiming.

X-Ray Kill Camera: One of the series' standout features is the X-Ray kill camera. Players will see a detailed animation showing the bullet's journey and its effects inside the body when they hit the enemies they are aiming at.

Graphics and Atmosphere: The game's graphics and atmosphere are an impressive representation of World War II Italy. The detail of the maps and environmental design is stunning.

Community and Multiplayer Mode: "Sniper Elite 4" features online multiplayer modes. Players can test their aiming skills in various multiplayer modes with friends or other players.

Community and Reviews: "Sniper Elite 4" is popular among players who are interested in shooter games. Features such as the game's large maps, sniper mechanics and especially the X-Ray kill camera are appreciated by players.

Development and Publisher: Rebellion Developments is the developer and publisher of the game.

Conclusion: "Sniper Elite 4" is a viable option for players who want to experience sniper capabilities. Large maps, tactical options and details such as the X-Ray kill camera add to the game's appeal. If you are interested in third-person shooters, "Sniper Elite 4" may be an enjoyable experience for you. By checking out the game's community and reviews, you can evaluate whether the game is for you.

edit after 30hrs:

I tried multiplayer for a few rounds of CTF, it works well. Probably player count is low though. We had a 2v2.

A strange bug occurred to me, when I started the game, some videos kept playing in the background and the only way to fix it was to wipe the videos folder, except those that play directly before a map. (create new folder in Steam\steamapps\common\Sniper Elite 4\FMV and move everything into that)

For completitionists, replayability with the challenges and weapon masteries is surprisingly great, there are Steam achievements as well. Some challenges require you to be extremely stealthy, others specifically ask for a shotgun, always able to spice up your next 1-2 hours in a different way.

I would like a bit more options for suppressed rifles, but the one they added to the game can get you  ~200m range with reliable kills, and allows you to be stealthy without sound masks, making overall speed much faster... but this won't change and it's okay.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I first bought this game in December of this year, played for 11 minutes, and promptly refunded it thinking it was far inferior to SE3. I bought it again last month, and after 17 hours, I can say I was right the first time. For this review's context, I beat the game on hard mode and replayed on easy.

I hate how easy Easy Mode is. I get it's called easy but I was expecting *some* challenge. The suppressed sniper rifle they hand you makes the entire game so trivial. You can make some of the stupidest plays ever and the enemies won't bat an eye at you. You can run up to someone while they're in aggressive mode, go for a takedown, and not take a single point of damage.

The lack of "bosses" also stings. In SE3, you have to take down a tank or 2 to clear the level, but all the tanks here are optional to destroy. The only real "boss" is at the end, where all you have to do is fire your rifle 4-6 times without any sense of a threat from a single enemy.

I do think the weapon upgrade system was pretty neat, but the lack of other weapons really hurt. The only real weapons you can choose from are the ones you get at the start of the game, and ones you can take from German soldiers. Let me choose my gun in the menu!

I did however like the all the new mechanics. Climbing horizontally across and dropping down from ladders actually gave them a major use, unlike those in SE3 where they could've just put stairs. I also liked how you have to kill a tank's driver and gunner before being able to rig an explosive to destroy it, instead of just repeatedly chucking explosives at it. 

All in all, this game could've been a lot better, but did add a few new features. My word isn't gospel by any means, you decide if this game lives up to SE3.

After realizing that all close range combat was utterly and pointlessly easy, I decided to go for long shots, "sniping" one might call it. Things I didn't enjoy were that 80% of the buildings are static & non-functional servicing no purpose but to make the map into a maze for cosmetic purposes only. This reduced game play immersion especially on the Giovi Fiornini Mansion mission. I played the game for only using the best weapons and didn't fancy using any of the ones of lower quality. Each map can take multiple hours to complete if you're a completionist which is a good thing. The AI behavior is very predictable after a while even on the Hard and Authentic settings. Now THIS is a Sniper Elite game.
After the disappointment of SE3, this is a deep breath of fresh, cordite-scented air. Big, expansive levels, lots of sight lines, elevation changes... Go close-quarters or long-distance, whichever you're feeling at the moment. Some nice cinematic moments, and little bits of well-constrained storytelling at the beginning of each mission.
The cover system isn't the greatest, but it serves. You have to spend about twice as long finessing yourself into position as you should.
Enemy AI is fine - they still don't really understand height differences, which can make for some very funny situations, but they can put up a decent fight on Sniper Elite difficulty. On the higher difficulties they're quite deadly.
The gun upgrade challenges are kind of silly, but you don't need them at all, every gun is at least competent in its base form - and you're going to end up using the Welrod and your rifle in 99% of cases anyway.
Make no mistake - this game is not difficult, even on Hard (Sniper Elite) difficulty - but it is very enjoyable. It's a smile-inducing romp around Italy, stacking fascist corpses of every nationality like firewood in your wake, finishing with some good old-fashioned Wunderwaffe sabotage.

Easily worth full price.

I have been an avid gamer for many years, and I can confidently say that Sniper Elite 4 has truly exceeded all my expectations! This game has left me completely awestruck with its immersive gameplay, stunning visuals, and engaging storyline.

From the very beginning, I was captivated by the breathtaking environments and attention to detail. The developers have done an incredible job creating a world that feels alive and authentic. Whether I was crouched in the shadows of a ruined building or sneaking through dense vegetation, every location felt meticulously crafted, adding a whole new level of realism to the experience.

The gameplay mechanics are undoubtedly the highlight of Sniper Elite 4. The precision shooting system is incredibly satisfying, and landing that perfect headshot from a distance gives an adrenaline rush like no other. The bullet-cam feature, which showcases your shot in slow motion, is nothing short of exhilarating! It's both impressive and gratifying to watch the trajectory of your bullet as it finds its target with pinpoint accuracy.

Moreover, the variety of missions and objectives kept me engaged throughout the entire game. Each level presented unique challenges and opportunities, allowing for different approaches to complete the tasks. Whether I chose a stealthy approach or decided to go guns blazing, the game accommodated my playstyle and rewarded me with a sense of accomplishment.

I must also commend the AI design in Sniper Elite 4. The enemy's behaviors felt realistic, forcing me to strategize and plan my moves carefully. Their reactions to my actions were spot-on, making the whole experience feel challenging yet fair.

If you ever wanted to see what a tomato looks like after being hit by a high-velocity watermelon launcher, Sniper Elite 4 is your game!  This game takes "realistic gore" to a whole new level, and trust me, it's both disturbing and oddly satisfying.

Forget about Sniper Elite 5, because Sniper Elite 4 is the ultimate party-pooper pulverizer! üéâ You'll be laughing so hard at the over-the-top gore that you'll forget it's a stealth game.

It's 2023, and this game is still worth playing, especially when you need to let off some steam (pun intended) after a rough day. The satisfaction of popping enemy skulls like popcorn never gets old. Just be warned: you might develop a strange craving for watermelons afterward!

You get to kill hundreds of fascists and get to see their organs disintegrate. And you can kill Hitler.

It's a bit repetitive once you get into the gameplay loop of firing a couple shots and moving position to flank hiding enemies. The AI is too dumb when hiding from you and too aim-botty if you get pin-pointed. It has a flaw a lot of open world games have of giving you lots of options like traps and distractions and environmental hazards, but the most effective and least time consuming one is the straightforward shoot guys with silenced weapons or when there's a sound to mask your rifle fire method.

I wish the game took inspiration from Soldier of Fortune or Left 4 Dead 2 - the Mortal Kombat-esque x-rays are dandy, but I'd like to see some dynamic external carnage left in my wake as well.

It is a fun if not realistic or accurate representation of sniping.  The various difficulty levels, creativity of level design and variety of shots you can make are very cool.

Before anything else, I must specify that this game is not very OCD friendly; between all the exploding crates/barrels, all the destroyable lights and the UI bug in the main menu that doesn't update the "new" notifications, this game can stretch you pretty thin in the things you feel the need to do, so be sure to keep that in check.

That being said, it's far and away one of the best Non-Metal Gear Solid games on Steam in terms of gameplay. Ammo management is particularly stingy when it comes to long-range and/or stealthy options (my dude easily getting 150 loud SMG rounds within the first 5 minutes but unable to use any of it at range cause awful accuracy + compensating for bullet drop-off on iron sights, whereas he'd be lucky to find even 10 Regular Pistol rounds for his Silenced Pistol within the same time frame WITH the Item Search Upgrade) and wind mechanics have absolutely no business being in indoor-based missions, but otherwise everything else is pretty great and in-depth, coming quite close to MGS3 and onwards in terms of options. Word to the wise, though: if you do wanna go in guns-blazing (and actually use half of the weapons available to you) outside of the easiest difficulty, you better bring in your shooting A-Game, or you'll be eaten alive by the German War Machine.

In terms of story, it's definitely not much to write home about, being closer to MGS3 in terms of simplicity and easiness-to-follow; I'll give it points for making it feel like actual italian-flavored wetwork most of the time and making the Nazis particularly ballsy as you're always playing catch-up with them, but some voices like the local resistance leader just weren't delivered too well. The music is fitting enough given the timeframe and some tracks are at least worth a re-listen, but most of them are rather forgettable and I've even had a few issues with music triggers in-game, so don't expect any Snake Eater's or Heavens Divide's here.

All in all, it's definitely worth picking this game as a good alternative to the Metal Gear Solid series, and make sure to get the "Season Pass" DLC Collection as well; with all the good weapons and all the extra ways to kill Hitler, it's totally worth it.

Very solid game. Its' very much a specific brand of sandbox game that is rather rare since it specializes in one mechanic stronger than others. Which for this series is sniping. 

+ Controls are very intuitive
+ Actions are smooth and responses are smooth no real clunk with anything but crouch walking up steps
+ Can play however you want, stealth is given incentive but if you like letting things fall as they do, you can play this game how you wish. 
+ World is dense with content befitting a sniper game 
+ Did not play this game's MP however, still has a variety of modes available (Campaign, Survival, Overwatch) 
+ Great co-op experience 
+ The community are all rather polite and nice (yes this actually matters) 
+ The x-ray system is extremely satisfying 
+ Music is much better than I'd imagined it being. 

- Weapon variety is relatively low for base game
- DLC weapons outclass the base game weapons by a mile 
- Some weapons serve different functions but there are some weapons that render another's obsolete by sheer existence
-/+ Stealth system is rather basic for how it tries to present itself. Despite that, it works well enough that it's not that big a deal.
- Story is remarkably generic

Overall, there is nothing from a game aspect that I could truly complain about. The game felt fair all around. You are rewarded and punished for good/bad actions respectively and nothing really feels cheap. If you are skilled enough you can truly escape from any situation, maps are open allowing for any style of play and the game is just a satisfying experience.

Another game franchise that i neglected for years that turned out to be amazing the way you can takle every objective in your own order and pace gives a lot more realism to a game that on surface seems arcady the gun selection is good however a good portion of guns is locked behind dlc which i am not the biggest fan of gunplay however is amazing sniping feels super satisfying, level design was also good and although the game is linear you are given freedom to approach it how you want.The voice acting and facial animations where really bad compared to todays and even games of its time but again story telling is mostly told trough short movies before each mission so none of this dialogue with actual characters matters its a gameplay oriented game and those short moments where you do get to talk with other characters shows that.Sound design was nice a crisp and weapon sounds all felt powerful and close to being realistic.

Performance:
The game ran capped at 240fps the entire team on all ultra 1080p granted i do have a i7 13700kf and a rtx 4080 so im not sure if the powerful hardware was the result of stable framerate or just good optimization the visuals itself are not bad nothing crazy to write home about .

Overall a great experience solo and coop most of my playtime so far was with a friend but even solo i was able to enjoy the game a lot solid recommendation 9.2/10

Sniper Elite 4 is a standout entry in the series, offering a satisfying and strategic sniping experience set in a detailed World War II backdrop. With its impressive level design, realistic ballistics, and the iconic X-ray kill cam, the game delivers a unique blend of stealth, action, and precision shooting. If you're a fan of tactical shooters and enjoy the thrill of long-range sniping, Sniper Elite 4 is definitely worth considering.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
