Sniper Elite 4 is about the best game I have ever played. I like many games, and historically I have always favored strategy games. 
When DOOM came out, followed by Quake, and those series, I played those games, but they did not hook me as Sniper Elite 4 has.
The design of the game is superb; it is fast and responsive. Seldom have I encountered lag in playing the game.
The images and scenery are amazing. The attention to detail on the locations, buildings, scenery, clothing of the characters, weapons, vehicles and even the roads and ground you step on should by itself earn this game an academy award if there was one for games.
Of course, Sniper Elite 4 has the advantage of modern technology and fast computers that favor its model, unlike Doom and Quake, which began it all, but still I think Sniper Elite 4 is one of the BEST GAMES around and I find myself coming back to it again and again.
I play Cooperative most of the time and have found that a certain ‚ÄúCustom‚Äù setting gives me the most challenge without turning the type of play into a hide and seek game.
However, in my view, this is what makes Sniper Elite 4 unique, (and I say this with reservations because I have not played all the games to know): the ability to change settings in the game and have an entirely different game to play. The reason why this game is standing the test of time, at least for me, is because I can change settings, characters, weapon load-outs, go to a different mode of play, and I can spend hours discovering new strategies, learning the responses of the enemy and battling to win.
The AI in the game is amazing, and the AI seems to learn from your habits to pick at your weakness and get the advantage on you. 
Can the game improve? Of course. Does the game have bugs here and there? They all do, but overall this game is a top contender, and I argue The TOP contender in the genre.
Summarizing, I think Rebellion has made a fantastic game that entertains, challenges and gives people hours of clean, fun entertainment.

Cheers, Rebellion, for a job well done.

Sniper Elite 4, it takes what Sniper Elite 3 tried where they did away with the linear story in a single line map and gave you the map and the primary and optional objectives, the collectibles and everything in between. It gives you a bunch of weapons, customization, levels and skills that you can actually use to assist in your specific play style. The maps look gorgeous, the stealth aspect of the gameplay is amazing, it is dynamic and the opportunities for ambushing, trapping or even just sniping to your heart's content is great.

Highly recommend this game to any sniper loving gamer out there.

If Sniper Elite 5 is even bigger than this game, then I'll get it pretty soon, I just won't pre-order anything ever again, thanx EA and BF2042.

This game is one of the trademark games in the franchise, this one is loads of fun and has a great story. The missions are way bigger in scale all the maps are bigger in size making for great game play with loads of options on how you want to attack the mission even if you prefer stealth, going loud, or a combination of both you can do it. The game has eight mission like Sniper Elite 3 and all missions are different with lots of good scale and beautiful landscapes ranging from forest settings to snow settings night mission and others the game is beautiful. The gun play is a major increase in smoothness from the other previous titles you have lots of snipers to choose from if you have the DLC's for the game then you have loads of Snipers, Smgs and pistols to choose from I used the Carcano rifle and the Kar98K through out the game because they are two of my favorite rifles both in game and real life wise. The voice acting was awesome in the game and at one point of the game you get to befriend the mafia in Italy the game has a big twist and its a very interesting story. The multiplayer is still some what alive you can usually find a couple of Team Deathmatch games going on in early hours of the day ranging from noon to late evening which is loads of fun as well. There is coop in the game for the story as well as "survival mode" with three maps to choose from where you face off against waves of Germans the survival modes can be completed there are 12 waves in total. Overall this game was really fun had beautiful graphics great gun play and awesome open maps allowing you to play the way you want to I 100% recommend this game for people that like the other games in the series and also for new comers to the series! 5 Stars!

This is a good game... but then it's just the latest in a series of good games. But it is disappointing. 
The level design is excellent, the shooting physics  are still great but all the superficial rubbish is pretty annoying, unfortunately the latter is the majority of what this game adds. The main offender is weapon masteries: weapons get better if you do certain tasks using them, which is fine in theory but some of them are just plain stupid (50 kills over 40m with a pistol with no zoom... fun) and all of them take way too much effort for me to want to master all weapons. It's just grind to add length to the game.

Overall - go play Sniper Elite 3, if you've played that and are looking for more, maybe give this a go...

Sniper Elite 4 is, of course, a sniper game. However, unlike Sniper: Ghost Warrior and the franchise that it represents, SE4 is actually good, and the developers have their heads on straight. As far as I know. At least for this numbered entry, and the previous one. So, what makes this sniper game different from Sniper: Ghost Warrior?

Well, for starters it's in third person. This means that there are some small issues with the way you shoot, and impacting walls, but for them most part this isn't a huge problem. Some of the rocks in the 'release campaign'  have hitboxes which seem to be larger than the visual object itself, but it's nothing a small amount of repositioning can't fix, and it's not on every map. The sniping itself is satisfying, even if the bullet physics on 'Authentic Plus' difficulty are so ridiculously inauthentic that it almost hurts, but if you can get past the idea that this isn't a simulator, you're in for a good time. 

DO NOT go into this, expecting realism. There is nothing realistic about this game. You're a lone sniper that kills hundreds of nazis before lunch. Every mission. Realism isn't in the books here but that doesn't mean it isn't fun. The kill-cams are fun to watch (especially when the physics go wild), and there are enough guns and challenges to keep you occupied for a while. The story is... well, let's be honest: You didn't come to a sniper game for a story, did you? I hope not. You're looking in the wrong genre. 

That being said, it's not really a sniping game anymore. It's more like a 'commando' game. Use your smarts and wiles to outflank, outmaneuver, and out-ambush your enemies with a plethora of weapons and gear ranging from semi-automatic rifles, to vehicle-disabling mines, TNT, satchel charges, 'bouncing-betties', submachine guns, and more! The world is your oyster, and this might be the biggest version of Sniper Elite yet, except for the 5th game (Which I haven't tried yet, but I hear good things about). 

If you want to shoot nazis in the face, blow them up with explosives, and generally have a dang good time of it, in a relatively beautiful game world where sneaking and sniping are just as effective as quickly running and gunning (and everything in-between), with each approach presenting their own challenges, then this is the game for you. 

Some small things I was impressed with:

- if an enemy is 'downed' by you, but not killed, then other enemies may try to medically assist them, even carry them to safety. 
- Units can respond to calls from across the map, but it takes them TIME to arrive.
- Use the binoculars to find out some neat stuff about the people you're about to shoot in the face. Or feel bad about it and decide not to shoot them in the face (until you inevitably screw up, get spotted, and have to shoot them in the face anyways).
- Most guns feel unique, despite being WWII derivatives. 
- Co-op is FUN! Wow, how hard is it for a developer to make a co-op campaign that just... LETS you do all of it with a friend, balance be damned? Apparently not VERY! It's as if games are meant to be fun, and balance isn't the end-all! I've had a blast playing with a friend in both survival and on the campaign. Each time is a little different for some reason, and we've actually done the same maps over a few times just because we were enjoying ourselves. How many games can you say both permit this AND are fun? Not many, I'd wager. 

TL;DR: Don't buy Sniper: Ghost Warrior (or any of its franchise names/numbers). Instead buy this game, because it's GOOD and FUN and the developers KNOW HOW TO LET YOU HAVE A GOOD TIME!

As i sit in my trench enjoying my pasta, planning my next move, I only have one thing on my mind... balls. Was it something to do with my side dish of olives? Or was it a different type of hunger? For some reason I just wanted to explode them.

I laughed and cried as the skin was obliterated into a thousand flappy fragments and juice was dispersed all over my rough unshaven face. Pure bliss.

The game is fun, the action is amazing and coming up with fun cool ways to get past guards or going straight through them is satisfying. The game reminds me of Splinter Cell: Blacklist but more challenging, and keeping to the comparison, I'd prefer Blacklist's story even though it was not that engaging. In short game play is fun, story? Not so much but it is forgivable.

I thoroughly enjoyed playing through the single player campaign more so than any other game since mad max. So I played through on the easy difficulty to ease myself into the game, I was rather surprised though that after 13.7 hours (according to steam) that the campaign was over. The missions are pretty long taking an hour or two to try and do all side missions etc but the game still felt like it had been cut short.
I'll probably dive back in and play through on a higher difficulty in the future but if your like me and are not interested in the online multi player stuff then the full price isn't worth it. I was lucky and took a gamble on it in the 2022 summer sale and am glad I did. Anything more than 20 dollars or 20 euros just to play the single player stuff I'd say isn't worth it.
It is a really fun game though - just wait for the sales.

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Sniper Elite 4 is satisfaction guaranteed if you like sneaking about and shooting guys!  I have had a blast completing the missions throughout Italy.  The sneaking mechanic is perfect, you basically have to stay out of eyesight in order to avoid detection.  There are no bullshit spotting glitches that I know of; this game does a really good job of being fair when it comes to detection.  The sniping mechanic is easy to understand and makes you aware of how bullets don't always line up on the crosshair.  Sniping baddies gives me great satisfaction, and there's good chance you won't be spotted by the shot; even if you are spotted, the game is forgiving even on Hard difficulty if you have common sense.  Just don't stay in the same position!  Move frequently and you'll avoid having to break out your Thompson for close quarters combat against multiple baddies.  If you're REALLY good you can sneak up right behind a baddie and do a stealth kill that avoids using a bullet and avoids detection entirely (unless you're near another baddie, sometimes they spot you while you're killing the baddie).

I bet every sniper wishes they had a GPS location on all baddies in the local area, because that's how you remain alive as an elite sniper ... it's really easy to check your GPS and avoid teams of baddies without needing a direct line of sight.  Avoiding heavy patrols once you've dispatched a baddie is overwhelmingly satisfying on the sneaky-sneak tip!

Medkits and bandages are plentiful even on Hard difficulty.  If you screw up and get shot a bit, those medkits will restore basically your full health, or bandages a generous portion of it.  I found staying alive to be rather easy due to this fact.

If I had any suggestion for improvement, it's that sometimes you can get caught in a checkpoint blender where you're red (spotted outright) and you have no time to change your fate.  Multiple autosaves would solve this dilemma, as well as more generous manual save slots ... why the limitation to several save slots?  Just make them infinite, so you can easily re-live certain moments in the action without the need to frequently save over those moments.

Overall, this game is a delight to play, and it's a bargain now that it's a few years past new.  I highly recommend Sniper Elite 4 if you're looking for more stealth-based shooting.  You can even get into firefights without getting killed if you're skilled enough after you're spotted, so the game's forgiving even on Hard difficulty.  There's a difficulty threshold for every type of gamer out there, and you shouldn't be disappointed if you're looking for a challenge!

I picked up this game on a whim and a sale but came away very impressed (first Sniper Elite game I have played).  It reminds me of the original Call of Duty/Medal of Honor games, back when single player was everything instead of an afterthought.  

+ Graphics are very good but not super realistic. 
+ The level design is solid along with excellent art design.  Lots of fun areas and alternate routes to explore.  Feels like more of a "real world" than the painted-cardboard backdrop of some games.
+ Mission designs are fun, interesting and relatively varied.  Players can choose the order to tackle objectives in which increases replayability.
+ Enemy variety is just enough to make them seem less cookie-cutter than many WW2 games.  AI will attempt to flank you and they avoid falling for the same trap twice.  If you shoot from one spot too long then the AI will find you and attempt to rush or flush you out.
+ Fun game play and "pop goes the Nazi" never gets old.
+ Lots of collectibles to find/unlock along with "challenge" objectives.
+ Lots of difficulty levels including custom?  I played on "normal" which was not very tough but still fun.
+ I still remember that first [spoiler]"Hmm. What if I snipe that mofo's grenade?"[/spoiler] moment.
+ Game shows a high level of polish overall, probably lessons learned from 3 previous games?  It also feels like the devs cared about the game they were making, more so than a lot of other AAA titles these days.

+/- + 8 large main-game levels + 4 large DLC levels.  
+/- I have 50 hours in the game+dlc right now, still hunting collectibles/unlocks/etc.  Probably finished first full play through at around 40 hours while taking my time?
+/- You can use the sniper rifle mechanic to 1SK your way through the game, if you want.  I suppose that is literally the name of the game though, right?

- [spoiler]A dude with a rifle taking out tanks???  :lol:[/spoiler]  It was fun though, I will admit.
- Lots of available weapons but they are not super compelling to use.  They do provide "more stuff to level-up/unlock" though.  
- You can see some level design choices that look like they were made to improve game play but at the cost of some realism.  The game is probably still better as a result though.

! - The DLC adds some great new missions and is definitely worth it so I'd recommend the deluxe edition. 
! - The game gets some great discounts on Steam sales so plan accordingly.

[TL;DR, ‚òÖ‚òÖ/out of four rating]
If you are in search of a sniper oriantated sandbox environment, then yeah, this might be something for you. However, if you are actually in search of a decent stealth game, then stay far away from it. Let me go into more detail.

[DIFFICULTY & AI]
This game is way too easy in order to call it a proper stealth game. Enemies frequently have difficulty spotting you even if you run up on them, whereas other times they spot you instantly in the most well-covered areas. Firing an unsurpressed or covered shot might make the enemy aware of you, but they will just as quickly forget that it even happened to begin with. This might show you how painfully stupid its AI is, which ruins any real challenge there is to this game. This also eliminates the suppossedly important decision on which weapon to use. Should you go loud and risk blowing your cover or try to be stealthy and unseen. It. does. not. make. a. difference. You get rewarded either way for it, and it's not like the AI actually cares about it. I also enjoy how this game thinks that the player is actually brain dead. It constantly shows enemies on the minimap without them even being discovered or marked by you. Or how about those annoying markers that you can't turn off and will constantly float around unless you play the gamebreaking "authentic" difficulty mode, which artificially increases the difficulty by removing the entire HUD and making enemies uncanny tanky? Have fun having to shoot some helmless soldiers twice in the head before they die. It's downright awful.

[THE LITTLE GOOD THINGS]
Visually speaking, this game looks stunning. There is also a relatively sizeable array of weaponry, tools, and environmental destruction which can be used to kill the enemy forces with at least some variety. To be totally honest with you, most of the rifles do not feel any different which is a huge let down about a sniper rifles focused game but at least there are some expeceptions to this. The German-speaking soldiers at least sound authentic (which is rare in video games, trust me and take it from someone who natively speaks German). Also the levels are huge, even if the size sometimes feels a bit pointless.

[SOUND DESIGN]
Why did the lead sound designer think that its a good idea to constantly duck the audio when getting hurt, being low on health, being out of stamnia or just doing apparently nothing. I can at least say that the rest of the game sounds decent, but this right here is a major issue for me. It is just plain annoying and forces you to either never use up all of your stamina or being at full health all the time.

[CONCLUSION]
Stay away if you are in search of a good, fair, and challenging stealth game. I also cannot believe how they are still trying to sell this game as a full-priced title despite being 5 years old. If you are interested in a snooze fest, the sandbox funnies, shoot the F√ºhrers one testicle x-ray moments and than this game is MIGHT BE worth a buy at a high enough discount. I would, however, just go for any hitman game instead.

Sniper Elite 4
Review

	I have been following the Sniper Elite series for years now and I‚Äôve finally gotten a chance to try it out myself. This is my official review for Sniper Elite 4. 

1.	Movement: I feel the movement needs to be a little smoother. The mouse feels slow and sluggish when shifting my view form side to side. The walking movement is fine, just the mouse is a bit slow. 
2.	Gameplay: The gameplay is amazing as expected. The AI is well aware of everything the player does. From an AI perspective, this is probably one of the most realistic games out there in terms of how the AI behaves. 
3.	Story: I really like the story. It does feel quite authentic given the circumstances. I think the story lays out a proper feel for what sniping was like in the WW2 days. 
4.	Weapons: The rifles are well balanced and realistic. The SMG‚Äôs need some work. They are unrealistically inaccurate and hard to use. The pistols like the rifles are quite authentic and well-equipped for close quarters.
Already have on both Xbox & Playstation but couldn't pass up this price for the deluxe edition.  Wanted to have on the go and surprised it runs very well on my laptop (Intel Iris XE i5-1135g7)

This is a fun and potentially challenging game. Yes it is a bit gory at times (only in the kill cams) and you can cause some rather impressive mayhem. Depending on who you invite to play coop with can compound the mayhem and consequently the entertainment value of this game.

Sniper Elite 4 is one of the games I picked up for a Deluxe Edition on sale and it's worth 100% of your money. Not only I spend over 100 hours playing this game three times for causal, sniper elite plus difficulty, and co-op along with survival waves. This game may be small, but I get everything in the game to have 100% completion on achievements to make it worth it. The survival waves is challenging by playing by yourself. Sniper elite plus is very difficult since you have to do play each mission without dying and dying on that difficulty is hard to avoid since there's also almost no hud. Yes, getting every achievement in this game is easily possible with a friend especially some achievements that required co-op or multiplayer. If you want to play sniper elite 4 first over the other sniper elite games, I say this is the first one I recommend you should play :3

I'm 51 years old, my son set me up with a steam account and recommended some "essential" games.

I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised with Sniper Elite 4. I wasn't sure what to expect, but the game was a lot of fun. It's a bit of a thinking man's shooter, and I found myself really enjoying the strategic aspects of the game.

More often I found myself using stones and other methods to distract the German soldiers and it was fun.

The visuals are absolutely stunning, and the level design is some of the best I've seen in a while. The game is also pretty challenging, which is great. It's not easy, but it's not impossible, and I found myself really enjoying the process of working out the best way to complete each level.

I would definitely recommend Sniper Elite 4 to any shooter fan, and especially to anyone who enjoys a good challenge. It's a great game, and I'm really glad I gave it a chance.

I have finished the game on normal difficulty, and did all the side objectives. Have not tried co-op or pvp, and here's my opinion on this game.

TL;DR: Buy on sale, satisfying core gameplay but there are somethings in there not everyone will like.
Instead of sniping most of the time the majority of your playthrough will be 30% Sniping, 50% Sneaking around and stealth kill, 20% "Oh f*ck I messed up time to gun everyone down." Your mileage may vary.

Pros:
-The main appeal of the game is the X-Ray cams and they live up to their expectations. I was expecting them to get old after a few times but I have finished the game, seen it at least a few hundred times and it is always satisfying. Really makes you feel like a sniping god even though all I did was waiting for the diamond to turn red and clicking my left mouse button.
-Stealth mechanics, which you will do, like a lot, is fairly well designed and feels mostly fair at least on normal.
-Game looks really good graphically even for 2022 standards. The loading time is lightning quick for how big each of the maps are. A few minor poppings occassionally but no performance issues/frame drop other than that.
-The gadgets are pretty interesting and fun to play around with, mines, C4 etc etc. Nothing that will make you amazed but still good variety of tools at your disposal.

Cons:
-For someone that came into the game fully expecting to be sniping all the time, I felt that I was punished quite hard for sniping. Killing more than 3 ppl within 150m is like an instant cover blown as they can manage to triangulate you with pin point accuracy. The game imo is really the most fun in big open wilderness maps where you can hit things from across the map and feel bad*ass. Sadly the majority of the game and ESPECIALLY the last level are either indoors or very close quatered in nature. Is not necessary a bad thing as I have finished MGSV and had a lot of fun, its just not what I was expecting.
-Some animations, hit box and camera can be quite wonky in CQB scenarios, and you will have to go through them quite a lot.
-The story and characters are very weak. Which didn't bother me all that much as I came in just for the snipe cams, but if you are buying this for the narrative for whatever reason, just don't. The plot is forgettable and uninteresting. Characters often either so stereotypically portrayed that it becomes funny. Especially a certain main character that is so uninteresting and hard to sympathize with, that when he/she died at the end which was supposed to be the bombshell I was totally unfazed.
-Cutscenes somehow looks worse than the actual game. They are decently animated but I think the models are showing its age and it is hilarious sometimes.
-Most of the snipers shoot the same. Now this is a problem because there are a lot of them to choose from, and they all look pretty interesting but functionally they all behave and perform the same as your starting rifle, at least on normal difficulty with no upgrades. You may have different experiences as I have only played with like 6 or 7 of them and I have assists on.

Verdict: 6.5/10 buy on sale

For the TL;DRers‚Ä¶
[olist]
[*]The synchronicity between the bullet impact and the death animations are smoother and more accurate. (This is nothing to gawk over.)
[*]The levels have more angles and routes to cover, but the lack of masking opportunities still exist.
[*]The revamped interface reads and feels great, but the interactions themselves could be better.
[*]Customisation doesn‚Äôt add anything significant to the gameplay.
[*]The story is just 10-15 hours of white noise to sleep through.[/olist]

I feel as if I‚Äôve understood and enjoyed everything the Sniper Elite series could offer me at this point. SE 4 salvaged SE 3‚Äôs level design, revamped the interface, and made the entire gameplay experience much more enjoyable. SE 5 is basically SE 4.5, if the reviews and gameplay are anything to go by. Though key gameplay elements were changed, they made it worse to play the game. (Short jump heights kill you, crouch-running is removed, and other face-palming changes).

"Invasion Mode" sounds amazing, but it's not worth $50 to me, especially if I consider how alive the multiplayer would be years from now.

Of course, if you have a partner and fellow Sniper Elite fan to play the mode with, then it could be worth it for you. Otherwise, it‚Äôs best to get the game dirt cheap, especially considering how iterative the gameplay itself is.

Anyway, back to SE 4. I won‚Äôt waste words talking about the story; it‚Äôs boring and boilerplate. Moving on‚Ä¶

The level design is the best part about the game. Compared to SE 3, the maps offer multiple routes to approach your targets and objectives, and more vantage points to snipe from. In addition to this, the stealth gameplay is enhanced further thanks to the addition of shrubs and bushes.

However, you‚Äôll soon find that the game was designed for two playthroughs, neither of which accommodate the use of snipers efficiently. For instance, the Welrod or knife dominate stealth playthroughs. Gung-ho playthroughs offer you an occasional chance to snipe, but the machine gun dominates close-quarters combat.

Logically, that‚Äôs fine‚Ä¶ but for a game about sniping, there‚Äôs not a lot of sniping you get to do. Sniping is too noisy for stealth; pointless in CQC. To address the latter, it‚Äôs not because they don‚Äôt work; it‚Äôs because it doesn‚Äôt make sense to use it. Shouldn‚Äôt the thrill of playing the game come from picking off targets from a long distance? You don‚Äôt get that a lot here.

The moments when you do get to snipe enemies from far off aren‚Äôt great either. Most of these areas don‚Äôt necessarily offer you a chance to mask your shots.

You‚Äôd have to infiltrate the area even further (in other words, leave your sniping nest) and then snipe from the masked spot. And sometimes, these spots were annoying because they don‚Äôt offer a great line of sight to your enemies. So you‚Äôre back to knifing/pistolling/machine gunning again.

This proves that bigger and better maps don‚Äôt necessarily mean you‚Äôd get an efficient sniping experience.
I remember back when I played the crap out of SE V2. There was no stealth. There were more sniping opportunities. Some enemies camouflaged with the environment, adding complexity to scouting for them. 

The tagging system wasn‚Äôt efficient, eliminating hand-holding; this genuinely made you feel like a proper scout sniper hunting his targets. The sound design added to the fear of being found. Every non-crouched step you took echoed through the hollowed ruins of buildings, potentially triggering enemies to investigate and hunt you down. This felt scary at times.

SE V2 was short, yet sweet and possibly the most ‚ÄúSniper Elite‚Äù you‚Äôd feel. Unfortunately, SE 4 isn‚Äôt that sort of experience.

The game is riddled with modernist game design that holds the player‚Äôs hand in every step of the way.

For example, the current user interface looks neat and the information on it is readable. But the interaction experience itself (how you collect items within the game world) is underwhelming. Why should I hold a button to collect something? Especially for six seconds? What‚Äôs the rationale behind such decisions? Why can‚Äôt we, like in some RPGs, have two inventories open so we can choose what items to loot and leave behind? Isn‚Äôt that a much more interactive experience?

The game may have a few accessibility options that are great‚Ä¶ but the challenge in playing the game itself is bland, if not non-existent.

Speaking of bland, the series‚Äô biggest marketing push is the Kill Cam ‚Äì like the X-Rays or Fatal Blows in the Mortal Kombat series. Since the past decade, their USP has been more or less described as ‚Äúmore realistic and grisly than ever‚Äù. That holds no value anymore.

To be a little bit of a troll here, can you imagine NRS coming out with a new Mortal Kombat entry going, ‚ÄúLook! Now the livers don‚Äôt resemble sweet potatoes during Fatalities!‚Äù Sure, it‚Äôs a nice feature. Is there a gameplay benefit, though? I‚Äôd say that while it may impact our perception of the game, it has zero impact on how it plays.

But let‚Äôs critique this feature anyway. I‚Äôd say SE 4 makes the kills you secure look and feel grislier indeed. Unlike previous entries, there‚Äôs no ‚Äúlag‚Äù that I found between bullet impacts and the enemy death reactions. The animations felt smoother and the impacts felt accurate. And that‚Äôs it; those were all the positive things I can say about it. Unfortunately, since SE 3, it‚Äôs been irrelevant and adds nothing new to the series.

If anything, a large part of its charm was lost because of how explicit the feature is. I don‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs got loads of detail. I just mean it reveals too much information to the player, so there‚Äôs nothing to surprise them with.

For example in SE V2, only the skull is highlighted when you land headshots. However, landing an eye shot meant the Kill Cam highlights the eyeball as well. This shows great implicit design in action; until the player lands that first shot, they‚Äôd never know that they could land such shots in the first place. So once that discovery is made, players feel more engaged, they‚Äôd attempt more shots like it, and potentially find other interesting discoveries. (The testicle shots took everyone by surprise!)

In the succeeding games, this information is readily available to the player. So they‚Äôre never excited to shoot a particular body part repeatedly. It‚Äôs unsurprising because we know what to expect and how to achieve that expectation. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ boring.

It‚Äôs the same thing I‚Äôd say about the customisation. At first I thought maybe the weapon stats didn‚Äôt matter, so I tried around four different rifles. (Some games use placebo data to fool players into thinking they have the ‚Äúfaster‚Äù or ‚Äúbetter‚Äù thing; arcade racing games do this with car stats.) If there were any standout factors, it‚Äôs the recoil control, the weapon sway, and the fire rate.

With those factors in mind, the rifles did feel different. But the Carcano was the perfect all-round fit. It‚Äôs not that its stats were ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than the other rifles‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs that the Carcano was ‚Äúless compromising‚Äù compared to other rifles. So players would be more inclined to use and stick to the Carcano. The rifles could‚Äôve been customised for certain playstyles or maps‚Ä¶ but I found none of that.

And what on earth would I do with my upgraded pistols and machine guns? I‚Äôm trying my best [i]not to use[/i] them, and the game forces you in situations where you have to. It‚Äôs awkward, and takes away the point of the experience the game is trying to sell us. They innovated upon a feature that is utterly irrelevant.

Overall, if you want a Sniper Elite game with a healthy amount of content, go ahead with this one. But if you want a respectable ‚ÄúSniper Elite‚Äù experience, go for SE V2. If you‚Äôre just curious, get either one (or both) on sale if you have a few bucks to burn.

Since it‚Äôs Rebellion‚Äôs most bankable series, let‚Äôs hope SE 6 is a different, more positive story.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h2]Sniper Elite 4 Review[/h2]
	
[h1]Storyline [/h1]
The Sniper Elite games usually take place during the WWII Era that involved the German Nazis & the infamous Fuhrer Adolf Hitler. Your main objective is always to hinder the German infantry & overthrow the Germans. 

All of the Sniper Elite games that have been released so far seem to have the same character as the Main Protagonist. An S.O.E sniper 2nd Lieutenant named ‚ÄúKarl Fairburne‚Äù. I was surprised when I found out all the parts had the same protagonist since I didn‚Äôt expect that in a game like this. 

The game‚Äôs base plot goes something like this:
[code]To free Italy from Fascism, Karl Fairburne was dispatched to Italy in 1943. Aside from that, Karl must prevent the Axis forces from using a new weapon that may put an end to the Allied resistance to the Axis Powers even before it gets started... As well as having to deal with an anonymous foe and an Italian resistance commander who distrusts the Allies.[/code]

I was too indulged in the gameplay to care about the story. But for real though, they‚Äôve put in a lot of effort to craft this plot. And yeah, don‚Äôt expect it to be historically accurate. 

[h2]Gameplay Mechanics[/h2]

Oh my god, this game has so many things to it that I don‚Äôt know where to start! They invested so much in making the sniper mechanics as legit as possible. To make things easier for both of us, let me break down each vital gameplay part in this game into different segments!

[b][u]Core Gameplay[/u][/b]

Well, the name of the game makes it very obvious. You play as a militant who happens to possess a sniper rifle as their primary weapon. Snipers are good for long-range & stealthy combat. But this doesn‚Äôt mean that you are forced to take that approach since you also have two secondary weapons which can be used in close & mid-range combat. In addition to this, you can perform environmental takedowns, which just adds more ways to kill your victims. 

Unlike some of its previous parts, this game has an open-world characteristic to it. You have free reign on how you want to approach the given objective. Most of the objectives involve taking out Nazis or deactivating/destroying stuff. The game currently has 8 missions that are included in the base game & 4 more missions that come as DLCs. That‚Äôs a lot of content & it takes over 10 hours to finish the game. 

[b][u]Weapons[/u][/b]

The weapon mechanics in this game are just [i]chef‚Äôs kiss[/i]. Every shot is so satisfying. To make killing more fun, they‚Äôve improved their X-RAY Kill Cam. You can literally see the body pass through the person, destroying the bones & organs it touches. It‚Äôs a very sadistic satisfaction that you get. 

Depending on the difficulty you choose, the sniper mechanics will differ. The easiest difficulty will make shooting a bit too easy since it eliminates all the factors that affect your bullet from reaching its target. But on the hardest difficulty, the sniper mechanics become almost realistic. You need to put in a lot of thought before shooting your shot. So many factors come into play including wind speed, wind direction, hand stability, heart-beat, bullet drop, etc. This ramps up the difficulty a lot. 

[b][u]Difficulty Levels[/u][/b]

 The game has 4 difficulty levels which offer completely different experiences. This adds a lot to the game‚Äôs replayability factor & offers a challenge to those who seek one.

[h2]Visuals & Audio[/h2]

Even if the game had shitty visuals, I am sure it would‚Äôve become popular for its detailed & precise gameplay. Lucky for us, the game has amazing visuals accompanying its fabulous gameplay. The level of detail put into everything shows us how passionate the developers were. You can legit feel the love the devs put into making this game. My most favorite part in the visual aspect is the X-ray kill cams. It feels satisfying to know where your bullet hits. The anatomic & gorey visualization of your bullet puncturing organs & breaking bones gives you sadistic pleasure.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] The game picks off the storyline from its previous parts. It‚Äôs pretty interesting although the gameplay is the main charm of the game.
[*] The weapon mechanics are almost realistic. (Well, it depends on the difficulty mode you choose)
[*] There are 4 different difficulty modes that give you completely different experiences. You can also make a custom difficulty mode by altering the difficulty of various aspects of the game. This adds a lot to the replayability rate of the game.
[*] The game has an open-world setting which gives you a lot of freedom. You can plan your approach for a mission as per your wish. 
[*] You have a lot of options when choosing your weapons for a mission. This allows you to choose particular weapons depending on the setting of the mission & the playstyle you want to follow. 
[*] The feature that caught my eyes was the X-Ray Kill Cam. It‚Äôs so gorey & satisfying. It makes killing enemies more interesting as where you shoot actually matters.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
To be fair, I don‚Äôt think the game has any cons. Well, this is my view. It may be different from other people‚Äôs perspectives. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

This game satisfied my love for sniper rifles. If you‚Äôre up for an ultimate sniping challenge, then go ahead & grab this game. Make sure to play it in the Authentic difficulty mode. Is it worth the price? Definitely! But the DLCs are a bit too overpriced. I suggest you buy the game along with the Season pass during a sale. This will guarantee you a full-fledged experience of what the game has to offer. 

Rating: 9.5/10

For a studio that doesn't have the budget as some of the bigger AAA studios have Rebellion has found a way to make another great game in a pretty decent series.  Just a couple gripes.  Enemy A.I can be pretty stupid which kind of makes it feel like shooting fish in a barrel at times, and secondary weapons need a drastic overhaul.  Sub-machine guns aren't the most accurate firearms in the world I know but man in this game they are TERRIBLE!  You'd do better just rushing an enemy if you are spotted and taking them down with a melee attack because you'll have to get that close anyway if you try to use a secondary weapon.  All in all though I love this game and have really enjoyed the time I spent in its brutal world.

The good stuff:
[list]
    [*]Realistic sniping.
    [*]Good graphics.
    [*]Great level design.
    [*]So-so, serviceable story, it's just there to justify the levels.
[/list]
The bad stuff: 
[list]
    [*]AI is questionable at times.
    [*]Multiple weapon choices, but 99% of them play the same.
    [*]Welrod breaks the game.
[/list]
Overall it's a good game, well worth when on discount.

In shooting games I always find it annoying how there's never a chance to replicate what it's like to be a sniper, eyeing your target then watching them and making sure you're hidden and that your fire won't alert any other hostiles. This game takes that desire and themes the whole game around it! Allowing the player to creatively kill enemies in numerous fashions! Whether that be up close combat, far away with a sniper, or even using objects in the area to kill them. The game's formula allows it to be played endlessly with new methods of killing enemies in new levels.
stealthy sniper

Super repetitive, got bored after the second mission but decided to keep on playing as I hate to leave games unfinished but just like Metal Gear Solid, I just couldn't - I had to uninstall an incomplete game once again. 

It feels and looks like an open world game but instead you get a sandbox level on a pretty huge map with objectives all over the place, I was interested in clearing each and every objective in the beginning, subsequently it felt like a chore and I just focused on the main objectives. Unlike MGS, there isn't really a point exploring except for achievements and enemies surround almost 3/4 of the maps so its difficult to move around the map quickly. 

The story is split into different levels/missions and you get to choose your loadout before the mission, which believe me isn't as great as it sounds because most of the weapons are locked behind DLCs and the rest you have to buy with points you earn from ranking up. The skill tree is also forgettable, it might as well not exist tbh.

The AI in this game is just horrendous. There are times where the AI just walks past me without even noticing and other times where I get spotted from like >100m away. Stealth kills are unique because the animation changes from time to time which makes it satisfying but the laughable issue is that that somehow enemies above/below me can hear or sometimes even the building across, like it makes having a stealth kill option useless. 

The slow mo death cam is the only positive thing about the gameplay, other than that its just borderline mediocre. Instead of equipping a silencer on your weapons, you have to scavenge for silenced ammo before you can shoot with a silenced weapon... yes you heard me right, silenced ammo LOL. The shooting itself is terrible, and somehow you can 1 hit headshot a solider wearing a helmet but if you headshot a sergeant/officer (not wearing a helmet), 90% of the time they don't die. 

The game itself isn't terrible, its just super repetitive and it had everything in Metal Gear Solid that I hated about. 3/10

One of my all-time favorites to coop play!  The Sniper Elite series is awesome.  There has been so much given to the artwork/style/cut scenes and voice acting that it makes the story superb to follow along with.  The missions are balanced enough that I feel like there is just the right mix of stealth and action.  The environment is beautiful and suspenseful to sneak through.  The AI is pretty good.  I like the way they will go other routes if they see they are being attacked from one direction.  The missions are neither too short nor too long and my absolute favorite thing about each level is that you can save it anywhere!!! I've got things to do and it's hard to always have to be able to devote two to three hours in a single sitting, so being able to save in coop anywhere and come back is perfect!

Was fun. Was able to finish in 30 hours while trying to finish all of the optional tasks. Didn't replay missions. DLC is up next. Game was immersive for me and mechanics were good but not great. It took a while to figure out how to play -- run & gun doesn't work. But I enjoyed the slower process of sniping and sneaking.

The best of the Sniper Elite series. SE4 takes the changes made to SE3 and expands on all aspects. The maps are larger and more open. There's more variety to your enemies (Italians are nice addition to the mostly German corpse pile). The cheese in the dialogue is increased. Plenty of weapon variety and environmental traps to play with. Story was actually surprisingly good (in comparison to a B movie, which we all know this is at heart).

It's a great bit of fun, and reviewing this years after release while the new SE5 is out, it is still a great but of fun. It's definitely better than the sequel.

Bad dialogue. 
Bad voice acting. 
Bad AI (they go from dumb to clairvoyant in a heartbeat). Once they're on alert, all they do is keep pathing from point A to point B in a loop. In one hilarious instance, one of the guards in alert mode decided to play a line of dialogue and started complaining abt the artwork of some artist! XD 
The level design was made with a stealthy commando in mind rather than a sniper.

Did you know that it can sometimes take double and triple headshots to kill enemies?

Enemy snipers just spawn on elevated towers or platforms but with no way to actually get up there. Really? So I can kill them but I can't climb up there to use that vantage point? I swear, it plays like a student project on a budget!

All they care about is the stupid wow moments of the xray shots and xray melee finishes which thankfully can be turned off. 

I wish a competent studio would make a sniper game. All we got is this and the joke that is Sniper Ghost Warrior.

Well, at least we still have Sniper Elite V2.

I simply love this game, and I'm currently doing yet another playthrough of it.

Graphics aren't much to brag about, and can't compete with most other games released around the same time. Don't expect too much here.

Maps are well designed, and have the correct size, imo. I like how missions takes you all over the map instead of just a path through it. I also like all the secondary objectives, giving you more goals to strive for instead of just rushing through the mission itself. And they're all optional, which makes them better. Exp for doing objectives could have been higher though, since you have to play through the game several times to max out your toon.

My only personal issue with the gameplay, is how you're "supposed" to mask the sound of your shots by waiting for other stuff to make sounds, drowning the sound from your weapon. Waiting for secondary sounds can take a VERY long time. For example, the first sniping tower on the very first map - it takes at least 5-6 minutes (probably more) between these sounds. Which is why I either go stealthy or don't care if they hear me, most of the times. Yes, I am aware that you often can make sounds yourself by starting generators to mask your shots, but they're not everywhere.

It's like they spent a lot of time polishing and ironing out bugs, because everything works as intended and controls are responsive, your toon do exactly what you're trying to do without any input lags or sluggishness.

Bugs. Are there any? Haven't encountered a single one. The game has crashed once, as far as I can remember, but that could be a million reasons why.

Price for this game is too high, imo. Because two days ago, the next game in the series was released, and that one is cheaper than SE4, which is weird. But it's still worth the price. It's often on sale, though, so I advice you to wait till next sale and grab it then. Because you really should buy this one, it's far better than the previous games.

It's a map pack for Sniper Elite 3. There are minor changes here and there, but it's largely the same. And you know, its still fun to click on heads.

The good:
* Multiplayer saves & quick saves are cool

The bad:
* Privacy Policy bullshit, no prompt to opt out on game launch, it's actually maliciously hidden away.
* Coop quality is still a bit flaky, we had issues with alert state not going away, weirdly loud sounds from the other player
* Voice acting sounds strange and subtly robotic for some reason. Don't know if it just me.
* The story is.. kinda hard to follow or give a crap about. SE 3 had more cohesive narrative, even if neither game has an interesting one.
* Weapon upgrade system is actually a downgrade. You now have to perform certain feats with the weapon equipped to unlock upgrades. Feats like kill 100 tagged enemies with a close quarters pistol for 1 upgrade. In a game about sniping. And if you care about achievements, you will be grinding that shit and not have fun sniping, which does ruin the game.
* Achievement for Authentic+ difficulty with no saves is trash, specifically the no saves part.

TLDR: The x-ray shots never stop being awesome, great level design for the most part, sub-par characters and voice acting.

You would think that the x-ray shot thing is a gimmick and that you'd get bored of it and turn it off after a while. Well.. You wouldn't get bored of it, definitely not on Authentic and Authentic+ difficulty levels because goddammit you earned that shot. I loved every single minute of it. You could also go for different play-styles depending on what you enjoy and even switch things around from level to level. The upgrades weren't all that impactfull in my opinion when playing on Authentic+ but they weren't horrible either

The level design is fantastic and offers you multiple choices to go about the level, planning it out using the map and tagging enemies before going in makes the strategic aspect of the game just as fun as blasting nazis' heads off. Although 1-2 levels were a little confusing if you're looking to be a completionist, overall fantastic.

My least favourite part was the voice-acting and characters. I like characters that I would remember for a really long time, and yes I'm not going to forget the characters in this game but.. Mostly because they were so plastic-y and hilarious (unintentionally of course)

After Rebellion released Sniper Elite 5 in May of 2022, the gaming industry looked like it was pretty much on its last legs.  Then, we were saved.  The Aztec Sun gods reversed time and put 2016 after 2022, and the much anticipated sequel to Sniper Elite 5, Sniper Elite 4, was released.  A true return to form, Sniper Elite 4 shed all of the mistakes Rebellion made in version 5, even reducing the demand on current hardware which was a welcome move given the chip shortage just a few years before left many gamers unable to upgrade their hardware. Focusing on what was right, Sniper Elite 4 proved that Rebellion really could improve on it's mistakes.

You hit it off great at first, almost perfect.
She promises you a great time and a major commitment.
Immediately, you notice some red flags.
But she promises to work on them.
Issues continue to mount fast, and you're wondering if this is really worth your time.
She reassures you she is working on it and promises to be better.
After months of waiting, you hardly see each other anymore.
Things are stale and all those promises become a shell of what they were.
She comes up with an idea to take you out to eat at a fancy restaurant.
But she ends up taking you to Mickey Moaburgers instead........and makes you pay.
You keep telling yourself things will get better, but you know they wont.
She wont keep up on her end of the bargain.
It's time to let her go Chief.

I'm an absolute fan of this game. I've played (and replayed) Sniper Elite 3 quite a while ago and this 4th entry into the series improves a lot on the 3rd. One great thing about this is the replayability: you can go and do missions in whatever manner or path you wish.
Snipin Nazis has never been so fun.

Rebellion expanded upon everything that made Sniper Elite Africa good. In this amazing Sandbox, you get to make your own experience. You can make it about sniping Nazis and enjoying the slow-motion carnage, and skip the cutscenes and secondary objectives. You can also ghost the German Army, accomplish every objective, and never be detected, killing only the minimum enemies to avoid detection. And you can go gun's blazing and create chaos.

It is very similar to the Hitman trilogy Sandbox, and yet very different too. Some aspects could be improved, the graphics are good but in some parts, I can't tell if it's draw distance or lacks landscape details, but something looks plain and dated here, some textures like the Nazi's uniforms and trucks look amazing but some world textures look plain and unpolished. The weapon variety and customization are welcome, but also fails to deliver, as many rifles feel and shoot the same.

Despite its shortcomings, Sniper Elite Italy is an amazing experience for me. I would like a plot with more complex, deep characters and some storytelling elements. I guess the plot is an excuse to blow the brains of several Nazi officers and sabotage their evil plans once again, and that works for me too as the gameplay, ghost mechanics and sniping are awesome fun! There is a unique feel when you leave the area of operations after completing every objective without being noticed, you feel powerful as you ghost the German war machine over and over.

The storyline is nice and all. Solid. The MP though is a pile of steaming horse shit smothered in mustard and onions. 
5/10

A stealth game that didn't punish its players for going loud and just basically give one big playground with objective markers instead of putting long-a55 cutscenes is a "yes" for me.
Unlike most other games, the game didn't have "psychic" AI. They determine your position based on noise and last seen position, making it fun to flank them nutzees.

Compared to its predecessors, the game are less linear, there are more characters to be interacted with, and SMGs are not useless anymore. Also taking an armored vehicle is trickier given that there are less bullet-vulnerable weaknesses highlighted.

Looking forward for 5, where they finally add first person aiming for non-sniper weapons (something that MGSV: The Phantom Pain and PUBG made standard)

I would have given this game a solid 9/10 up to the point where the game started ‚Äòfreezing‚Äô up on me. The first time this happened was when I exited the game but steam showed I was still ‚Äúin game‚Äù. Had to exit steam before it showed I was no longer in the game.
Next issue was when I exited and the game froze my desktop to the point where nothing responded. I could Ctrl-Alt-Del where it showed that Sniper 4.exe was ‚Äònot responding‚Äô. Had to log out of windows before windows killed the program for me.** this has happened 4 more times since.
Third issue was when the game started ‚Äòfreezing up‚Äô on me while I‚Äôm still within the game itself. Ctrl-Alt-Del and sure enough, sniper 4.exe is not responding. 
At first I thought it was due to me walking away via long bathroom breaks, before coming back but this was disproven when it froze on me right after a sniper cut scene within the game itself. 

Googled the issue and found others saying the same thing. Strange part is that I had no issues up to the 4th or 5th map/level. Ran through the sniper training to get extra points to level up and it feels as if after this, I seemed to start getting these freeze ups. 

It‚Äôs a shame games like these spend so much time being developed just to suffer from strange bugs. I can‚Äôt image that Ctrl-Alt-Del and logging out is very helpful to simply stop playing a simple game but at this point that‚Äôs all I‚Äôm left with. Glad I didn‚Äôt spend more than the $9 as the games not worth more than that if its having this much trouble.

Dev‚Äôs or anyone else out there, I‚Äôm happy to try a fix if you know of one

This is a great game.

It expands and evolves on the the previous entry in many excellent ways, and is just an all around good experience. Too bad it's COMPLETELY BROKEN.

But only in a very specific way. After reloading a certain number of saves, the sound masking mechanic will cease to function properly. You can kick a generator to make it create noise at regular intervals, and the sound will still play. But the sound masking indicator does not appear, and if you fire a shot, enemies will react as if there is no sound masking at all.

Not only is this a game breaking bug, it's one that's existed since DAY ONE, FIVE YEARS AGO. It has not been fixed, and with the sequel releasing in a week or so, it likely never will. Do NOT give these people money in a product that has such deep flaws, and seriously consider whether you want to give them money for the sequel.

If I could get a refund after the amount of time I've played this game, I would.

At this point I am beginning to doubt Rebellion will ever create a game, where the general concept goes in pair with its gameplay. Sure, the maps are bigger, which potentially allows for more free playstyle and shooting enemies even from longer distance... but this honestly backfires badly, when in every mission you shove at least one if not 2 obligatory objectives that require you to run to pretty much the other side of the map, cause you either have to plant the satchel charge or pick up some textbook or pick a lock... essentially going the entire idea of sniper being a unit, that specializes in taking down enemies from a distance and causing havoc, by making the enemies never feel safe. And even when it seems like the objective for once going to be "kill this general" and you would be able to play it your way, Rebellion f**** it up badly by then making sure, you have to get right to its corpse. It's just so disappointing and seeing how CI Games, got from literally the worst possible sniping game, to something really junky but something that showed potential with Ghost Warrior 3 and then learned from mistakes by making Contracts and Contracts 2 constantly improving on their ideas and getting closer and closer with its level design and gameplay style to something that supports the whole concept of "sniping game" (even if, they are still really far from getting it right) - I just can't recommend this one. It's tedious and a chore to play with its horrible mission design... even if its engine at this point is very impressive.

Solid game, although too short for the full price. It's roughly 10-12 hours of gameplay unless you want to do 100% on each map which I do not recommend.

Pros:
-good story
-fun model of shooting with sniper rifles / good physics
-graphics is pretty good

Cons:
-price - each hour of gameplay costs u roughly 5‚Ç¨ 
-terrible SMGs shooting model and grenades that feel underpowered, you hardly ever kill anybody with grenades cause you cannot see where you throw them (it's pretty terrible)
-Game is 10-12 hours long and they did really bad job with the "filler" objectives - it's pretty much tedious grind of finding pieces of paper (in buildings and/or dead bodies that you get roughly 100-150 a map if you want to kill everybody)
-AI of goons - could have been better - they feel super stupid at times - they just run next to you if you stay in a brush(having shot previously so they heard it) and on the other hand they will get "wallhacky"with the bodies. They will legit kill ya through bodies before youu see them.

All in all, I've listed more downsides than upsides I guess, but the game is pretty solid. I've had a lot of fun playing it, and if you are just looking to kill some nazis - get it. On Discount. 15-20 euro would be okay I guess. I am going to get the season pass, although not on steam. Too expensive.

The funny game where you shoot nazis in the balls.
Starting out I'm happy to say that I had absolutely no performance issues, it's rare a game that looks this good can actually run this well. Sometimes the foliage dithering would cause a few drops but that's about it -- nothing frustrating or game breaking. 

The story is what it is, essentially just a wheel for the gameplay to keep moving. Nothing major, just take down Nazi operations and help the resistance or whatever.
The only reason I kept playing was the level of detail in how the game actually works; bullet gravity, wind, triangulation, the things I saw in the difficulty options and freaked out over. This is possibly the first shooter I've played (though I don't play that many shooters) where I actually had to think about where and how I was shooting. Especially trying to rack up as many ball shots as I can. Stealth can be a bit iffy but it's not like you get all that much for going 'ghost', and a lot of the time you'll want to stick to using Triangulation to your advantage anyways. Yellow alert status seems much harder to bait enemies to where you want to go unless you're throwing a bunch of rocks.

Multiplayer seems pretty dead but there's usually at least one or two lobbies open. I mostly just looked to see -- I was surprised there are servers still up. 
As for the price, for the 20 hours I got out of it personally I don't think I'd recommend it at the full ¬£40. But it seems like the game has sales, I managed to get it quite cheap, so if you really want to un-ball the Fuhrer I'd recommend not paying that much for it. And turn kill cams on frequent. It never gets old. Trust me.

This is a pretty fun game.  I can't speak to how realistic it is, but what is most important is that it feels fun going one-man-army on the nazis and feeling like a bad-ass sniper after taking out 100s of targets per mission.  However, it quickly can begin to feel monotonous.  

New guns, new enemies/vehicles, new maps and objectives keep things interesting for a while, but after seeing the kill-cam for the 10000th time, I am starting to feel like its a grind.  

The story is fairly weak but serviceable.  For more variety, I am looking at Rebellion's Zombie Army 4, which basically seems like a re-skinned version of Sniper Elite 4, but with Zombies and greater diversity of weapons and enemies, but haven't played it yet.

Good:
-Good graphics
-Maps are quite huge in size and the designs are insanely good, they are all aesthetically good looking, provide multiple routes to navigate, which make it fun to explore the maps besides just doing the objectives. The maps are much more open and gameplay no longer feel linear.
-Improved AI, enemies no longer has hypersensitive hearings so you don't have to crouch walking 90% of the time, enemies have much better danger awareness and realistic behavior. Overall, the enemies are less predictable than in 3 and V2. They still have insane eyesight,aimbot, and can be dumb, but at least not to the point of ridiculous.

Bad:
-Can still be repetitive, since you are doing the same things over again and again.
-Story is boring, but barely anyone cares about it anyway.
-Still too many DLCs, like 60% of the guns are behind DLCs, 4 out of 12 campaign missions are from DLCs, still a bit much. The season pass is dirt cheap in sale so just buy it since it has quite a large portion of the content
-ballistic physics can bit quite weird sometimes.

Overall, a much better game than sniper elite 3, would recommend for anyone who want to waste their time.

The lack of a step-by-step in-depth process can be dissuasive to newcomers.

Rudimentary stealth meets good sniping to yield around twenty hours of solid, if unexciting, killing and sabotaging to liberate Axis-occupied WW2 Italy.

There's little of interest beyond the core gameplay loop, owning to the outdated tech and abysmal writing, but there's also an undeniable draw to laying traps, backstabbing enemies and killing an entire company of soldiers. Most of this game feels strictly utilitarian, merely laying the groundwork to allow you to snipe and enjoy the brutal X-ray camera shots that portray bones and organs violently cracking and exploding inside each unfortunate Nazi on the receiving end of your brutal shots.

Those grisly moments are entertaining, but also the most interesting idea Sniper Elite 4 has to offer, and the low difficulty converges with poor and unrealistic AI to leave you relatively unpunished. This game is therefore best played as a poor man's Metal Gear Solid, infiltrating your way into compounds staffed by entire companies of soldiers. Dull as the stealth may be, sneaking behind enemy lines and wreaking havoc rarely disappoints. Vast non-linear levels with multiple objectives give ample opportunities to either hide or cause distractions on your freeform paths to what is usually either an assassination or item retrieval mission, which gives all the more reason to rely on stealth over distant sniping which quickly grows tiresome, no matter how elaborate the X-ray system may be. Killing a hundred Nazi soldiers with silenced pistols, explosive traps and neck breaking as you dart from cover to cover yields a perfectly reasonable time, and if you save the final three or four kills in the area for your sniper rifle, you'll get more enjoyment out of this mostly rudimentary experience. There are invitations to replay levels through optional objectives, new avatars, more weapons and equipment and modifications for each, but they aren't enough to overcome the rest of the game's blandness.

This is a classic example of a serviceable 6/10 title, offering few thrills but avoiding any major disasters beyond the plot, told primarily through skippable cutscenes. It's a bit dull, grows stale and other games have far better stealth, but it's a sum greater than its parts and the relatively unique premise makes it hard to not recommend, so long as you buy it on sale.

If I had to go to war, I've always thought I'd be a sniper. But in all other WWII games you are like a super human fighting nearly infallible ninjas, it's not realistic at all! I've been looking for a game that would give me a more accurate taste of what the real deal would've been... and this is the one!

Right off the bat I switched to hard difficulty, disabled the music completely, and turned off the visual aids for aim. The results are amazing! The gameplay is totally immersive, with endless possibilities to complete the missions in any way I want. There's nothing more realistic than that! And I can further increase the difficulty to experience even more realistic effects to ballistics. Will do, as soon as I get confident enough for it! Hehehe

And the camera? Just to stay closer to reality, I switched off the flagship X-ray cam (sorry, Rebellion)... but I was happy to know that I still could keep the awesome slow motion cam! And what about the steadycam when you run? So much fun!

You can tell they really thought about everything. What a great and fun game, exactly what I was looking for! I'll definitely play all other Sniper Elite titles.

Wanted to blow up a Nazi by shooting his grenade in hand or belt? You can do that.

Wanted to crush someone with deadly loads while being 500m away? You can do that.

Want to kill Hitler in a multitude of ways? Including shooting his singular testicle? You guessed it! You can do that.

It's. So. Satisfying!

This game has very little blood, and SE5 will have the same problem when it comes out. Now, I'm not talking about the X-Ray cams, those are awesome, the problem is they are the only satisfying way to kill the bad guys in this game. Using the other two guns just feels bad, there's no bullet wounds and very little blood splatter. Now that may make me seem like a psycho, but trust me, the violence in a shooter game goes a very long way towards replayability. 

This game has very poor stealth, maps that take way too long to run across, and graphics that are good except everyone looks like an action figure - but if at the very least the game had a nice bit o' gore, I think people would be coming back to it a lot more. Sniper Elite V2 and 3 both had that weird little pepperoni looking bullet wound, which didn't always work but it did the job and was always gratifying to see. Not sure why they took that out, or why they can't get something like that to work with every wound, or hell - why they can't just add bullet hole decals like many other games much older and newer do, but whatever. Also, there is no gore related to explosions, which is something every Zombie Army game has; same engine, totally possible, it's just missing in the mainline games. 

Playing through it once solo, then once again with a buddy, it was a really enjoyable experience. But coming back to the game this week just left me bored to tears. The bullet cam thing is definitely the coolest part of this franchise, and they are definitely refining that and keeping it cool, but wouldn't it be really cool if it could happen with any bullet from any gun? Wouldn't it be cool if when you see a man's skull explode in the X-Ray, then go walk up to him and actually see a big old hole where he was hit? Wouldn't it be cool if you could see limbs go flying when the camera cuts to your trap mine going off? I certainly think so, and it would have at least made the slower parts of this game more bearable - for me, that is. Sometimes the ragdolls really freak out and fly all over the place though, so that's pretty funny.

Recommending for the co-op, which is tons of fun, and the cool X-Ray system. Everything else is simply lesser than V2. Get it when it's on sale.

Hands down the best game I have played thus far in my life. People say "EW ItS NoT JuSt SnIpinG", but they don't realize a game just about sniping would be too complicated for general gamers, or too boring if they made it specifically for general gamers. You get to travel to various settings in Italy, see the beauty while sneaking through while taking down enemies and completing objectives. The weapons are amazing, nicely detailed. The mastery skins look brilliant on 90% of the guns. The mastery challenges are hard enough to give an extra challenge but are easy enough to keep pushing through. Maps are detailed as all hell get out. You can tell the game devs really tried and put passion into this game, like this game was made with love (which is weird considering its a WW2 game...) Its a big step from the past games. Enemies have some dialogue if you wait or explore.  The maps are great in their size with many routes and longshots you can take. The difficulties are great, different enough to stand out, but similar enough so the jump isn't bad. 
I had very, very, very few complaints. They would be the character dialogue and expressions, dialogue audio and then some small stuff. I love this game to death but oh my these characters should've gotten more detail and depth. The last quote at the ending about small sparks to a flame holds no meaning or importance if the girl had the personality of an angry rock. Dialogue audio (BESIDES THE MAIN CHARACTER!) seems sped up a little, its not terrible but definitely noticeable. 
The small stuff would just be a the fact a few mastery challenges can get cheesed really easily, and if I'm setting my graphics to a ultra quality, I want it ultra. My graphics card is less hot on Black Ops Cold War with ultra settings, than it is on high settings for SE4. And then, if you change your loadout and/or character, they will keep the same Karl voice, and will switch to default character and loadout in cut scenes.
And just hear me out for some more, please:
For people who just want sniping and only extreme hardcore sniping, calm down, take a breath and don't get angry, its like I said in the beginning. And those who want amazing characters that have more depth than a science book, I'm sorry you won't find that. But for people who like stealth, completing objectives, playing smart, and can take their time this game is 20/10. Thank you, Rebellion.

With good conscience that I could say Sniper Elite 4 might just be one of the best purchase I have made on Steam.
The gameplay, well, if you have been on boat with Rebellion, you know what to expect:
- Solid Sniper Simulator, including heart rate, blood splashes, and the trademark kill cam
- A variety of World War II firearms to choose from, and a lot more to be collect in missions
- A decent campaign with a good story. Good enough multiplayer, co op, and survival mode. Also, a shooting range.
- Lethal enemy(enough to take your life in a single shot), big maps(enough to take your real breath away)
- A lot of collectibles and ways to play the game

Graphically speaking, Rebellion has done a stellar job. Dust particle effect is awesome. The lighting is way ahead of any ray tracing technology. The world feels real, the people in it feel real, combat feels real.

Sniper Elite 4 offers little music, but packed with realistic sound of the war. You can actually feel the sound of machinery and aircraft blasting through your brain.

Sniper Elite 4 might need a decent gaming machine to run it properly(Gtx 965m and onward), but one you run it properly, you will be extremely happy with it. It also goes on sale with good price.

In conclusion, this is an absolute must buy, if you are thinking about buying it.

Sniper Elite 4 continues the series by being another generic third person CoD ripoff that focuses on snipers.
What is the point of this? Why is this an entire series with a spinoff that turned into it's own series???
Atleast this time the game is set in an interesting location not many WW2 games use. Being set in Italy helps this game look amazing at times, the levels in this game are varied and colorful, the mechanics feel slightly more refined than they were in SE3 and there is a progression system to unlock guns (most of which are locked behind DLC so it doesn't even matter). I just don't understand the point of this series, it's called Sniper Elite, the cool X-RAY thing happens when you shoot with a sniper, yet it seems like the game does everything it can in order to make sniping not enjoyable - If you shoot twice from the same general location you will be instantly spotted, I had to lookup how to get silenced bullets because the game doesn't explain that at all and once you run out of silenced bullets you can't get anymor, silenced snipers are paid DLC and you progress much faster by just rushing with your SMG.
The story is as generic as the story of the previous games. But this time there are also side objectives.... Rebellion tries every trick in the book to stretch out the game and it just doesn't work.
The standard edition is $60 and this is an outright scam. Without the DLCs the game has a very basic selection of weapons and not much content considering how generic the campaign is and how dead and basic the multiplayer mode is.
I don't understand why Rebellion refuses to let us have fun, give us more access to silenced bullets/snipers, make a more interesting story... DO SOMETHING!!! You could have involved some Italian resistance group in an active way, like in Ghost Recon where you can command a squad of 3 people, this way the player could organize ambushes, snipe a group of soldiers at the same time and do so much more.
Sniper Elite 5 is close to it's release and I can't imagine it would be much different from this game, but I just wish Sniper Elite 6 will be a turning point for the series.

This is a fascinating stealth game and a fascinating shooter game. However there's a huge flaw in game play design. The sniping is either too easy, if you turn aim assist on, or too hard, if you turn aim assist off or playing on higher difficulties.

I'm not saying you "can't" land your shots without aim assist, in fact there are numbers of pros can reliably pulling off long shots with tons of practice, but that's the issue. You gotta sink tons of hours grinding to let your muscle adapt to the very basic mechanics of the game, and that itself is a huge commitment and definitely not for everyone. But if you do enjoy the process of grinding your skills, the pay off is huge and this would be a legendary game for you.
